(c) The county will not make payments to any business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, for amounts charged by an elected official to any purchasing cards or credit cards that are not issued pursuant to this division or for any purchases that are not authorized by the ordinance codified herein. (Ord. No. 05-2015 , § III, 3-8-16; Ord. No. 01-2017 , 10-9-17) Sec. 2-184. - Card administrator. The board of commissioners shall designate a county purchasing card and credit card administrator. The responsibilities of the card administrator include: (1) Manage county-issued purchasing cards and credit cards. (2) Serve as the main point of contact for all county purchasing card and credit card issues. (3) Serve as liaison to the elected officials authorized to use a purchasing card or credit card and their staff, as well as to the issuer of the purchasing card or credit card. (4) Provide training on card policies and procedures to the elected officials authorized to use a purchasing card or credit card and their staff. (5) Develop internal procedures to ensure timely payment of cards. (6) Assist authorized elected officials to dispute transactions when necessary. (7) Establish internal procedures to ensure compliance with this division, county procurement ordinances and policies, county purchasing card and credit card user agreements, applicable agreements with the business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, issuing card, and state law, specifically, O.C.G.A. §§ 16-9-37 and 36-80-24. (8) Document internal controls, audits and other measures to prevent and detect misuse or abuse of the cards. (9) Review and reconcile transactions monthly. (10) Maintain records for at least seven years or as otherwise provided by the county's record retention policy. (Ord. No. 05-2015 , § IV, 3-8-16; Ord. No. 01-2017 , 10-9-17) State Law reference— Designation of a purchasing card or credit card administrator, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-24(c)(6). Sec. 2-185. - Use of cards. (a) Authorized purchases. (1) County purchase cards and credit cards may be used to purchase goods and services directly related to the public duties of the authorized elected official only. All purchases are subject to the terms of the ordinance codified in this division, the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement, county procurement policies and ordinances, and the adopted budget. (2) Only authorized elected officials may use a county purchase card or credit card for purchases or payments. The cards, and use of the cards, are not transferrable to employees. The authorized elected official shall use care to ensure that others do not have access to the card account number, expiration date and security code. (b) Unauthorized purchases. County purchasing cards and credit cards shall not be used for goods and services not directly related to the official responsibilities of the authorized elected official. Additionally, cards shall not be used to avoid compliance with the county's purchasing ordinances and procedures, to purchase goods and services that are not approved in the county's budget, to purchase goods and services exceeding the per transaction or per month limit, or to make purchases not in compliance with the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement. (c) Receipts and documentation. Receipts, invoices and other supporting documentation of all purchases made with a county purchasing card or credit card shall be obtained and maintained by the authorized county elected official for five years or as otherwise provided by the county's record retention policy. If an original or duplicate cannot be produced, a sworn affidavit of the authorized elected official may be substituted. The documentation must include the supplier or merchant information (i.e., name and location), quantity, description, unit price, total price, price paid without sales tax, and an explanation of the purchase sufficient to show that the expense was in the performance of official county duties. (d) Public records. All receipt and other documentation of purchases are public records and subject to the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70 et seq. (Ord. No. 05-2015 , § V, 3-8-16; Ord. No. 01-2017 , 10-9-17) Sec. 2-186. - Review of purchases. Proper documentation of purchases, internal controls and other measures prevent and allow detection to misuse or abuse of county-issued purchase cards and credit cards. Authorized elected officials and staff that process payments under this program shall cooperate and comply with the procedures established by the county. (1) Review of purchases. All purchases shall be reviewed according to the following procedure: Approval of purchases by elected official; approval by card administrator that the elected official has approved purchase. (2) Review. The card administrator shall perform an annual review of the card program to ensure adequacy of internal policies and procedures, cardholder spending limits, monthly reconciliation procedures and documentation for transactions. Elected officials and staff shall cooperate with such review. (Ord. No. 05-2015 , § VI, 3-8-16; Ord. No. 01-2017 , 10-9-17) Sec. 2-187. - Violations. (a) An elected official shall reimburse the county for any purchases made with a county-issued purchase card or credit card in violation of this division or the user agreement. (b) In the discretion of the county governing authority, failure to comply with the procedures outlined in this division may result in: (1) A warning; (2) Suspension of the elected official's authority to use a county purchase card or credit card; or (3) Revocation of the elected official's authority to use a county purchase card or credit card. (c) Nothing in this division shall preclude the county governing authority from referring misuse of a purchase card or credit card for prosecution to the appropriate authorities. (Ord. No. 05-2015 , § VII, 3-8-16; Ord. No. 01-2017 , 10-9-17) Secs. 2-188—2-195. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - RESERVED
Secs. 2-196—2-210. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - CODE OF ETHICS
Sec. 2-211. - Act in the public interest. Recognizing that stewardship of the public interest must be their primary concern, members will work for the common good of the people of Georgetown-Quitman County and not for any private or personal interest, and they will assure fair and equal treatment of all persons, claims, and transactions coming before the Commission of the Unified Government of Georgetown-Quitman County, Georgia, authorities, boards, commissions and committees. (Res. No. R06-07, § 1, 4-3-2007) Sec. 2-212. - Comply with the law. Members shall comply with the laws of the nation, the State of Georgia and the Unified Government of Georgetown-Quitman County, Georgia in the performance of their public duties. These laws include, but are not limited to: the United States and Georgia Constitutions; the Code of the State of Georgia; the Charter of the Unified Government of Georgetown-Quitman County, Georgia, laws pertaining to conflicts of interest, election campaigns, financial disclosures, employer responsibilities, and open processes of government; and the ordinances and policies of the Unified Government of Georgetown-Quitman County, Georgia. (Res. No. R06-07, § 2, 4-3-2007) Sec. 2-213. - Conduct of members. The professional and personal conduct of members must be above reproach and avoid even the appearance of impropriety. Members shall refrain from abusive conduct, personal charges or verbal attacks upon the character or motives of other members of the Commission of the Unified Government of Georgetown-Quitman County, Georgia, authorities, boards, commissions, and committees, the staff or public. (Res. No. R06-07, § 3, 4-3-2007) Sec. 2-214. - Respect for process. Members shall perform their duties in accordance with the processes and rules of order established by the Commission of the Unified Government of Georgetown-Quitman County, Georgia and authorities, boards, committees, and commissions governing the deliberation of public policy issues, meaningful involvement of the public, and implementation of policy decisions of the Commission of the Unified Government of Georgetown-Quitman County, Georgia by the manager and staff of the unified government. (Res. No. R06-07, § 4, 4-3-2007) Sec. 2-215. - Conduct of public meetings. Members shall prepare themselves for public issues; listen courteously and attentively to all public discussions before the body; and focus on the business at hand. They shall refrain from interrupting other speakers; making personal comments not germane to the business of the body; or otherwise interfering with the orderly conduct of meetings. (Res. No. R06-07, § 5, 4-3-2007) Sec. 2-216. - Decisions based on merit. Members shall base their decisions on the merits and substance of the matter at hand, rather than on unrelated considerations. (Res. No. R06-07, § 6, 4-3-2007) Sec. 2-217. - Communication. Members shall publicly share substantive information that is relevant to a matter under consideration by the Commission of the Unified Government of Georgetown-Quitman County, Georgia or authorities, boards, committees and commissions, which they may have received from sources outside of the public decision making process. (Res. No. R06-07, § 7, 4-3-2007) Sec. 2-218. - Conflict of interest. In order to assure their independence and impartiality on behalf of the common good, members shall not use their official positions to influence government decisions in which they have a material or financial interest, or where they have an organizational responsibility or personal relationship that may give the appearance of a conflict of interest. In accordance with the law, members shall disclose investments, interests in real property, sources of income, and gifts. Should any member be financially or otherwise closely associated with an issue, said member shall disqualify himself/herself from participating in considering the issue and shall not sit with the commission, board or committee during such consideration and they shall abstain from participating in deliberations and decision-making where conflicts may exist. A member may raise the question of conflict of interest of another member regarding a specific issue. A majority vote of those without such conflict shall determine if such conflict does exist. (Res. No. R06-07, § 8, 4-3-2007) Sec. 2-219. - Gifts and favors. Members shall not take any special advantage of services or opportunities for personal gain, by virtue of their public office, which are not available to the public in general. They shall refrain from accepting any gifts, favors or promises of future benefits which might compromise their independence of judgment or action or give the appearance of being compromised. (Res. No. R06-07, § 9, 4-3-2007) Sec. 2-220. - Confidential information. Members shall respect the confidentiality of information concerning the property, personnel or affairs of the unified government. They shall neither disclose confidential information without proper legal authorization, nor use such information to advance their personal, financial or other private interests. (Res. No. R06-07, § 10, 4-3-2007) Sec. 2-221. - Use of public resources. Members shall not use public resources that are not available to the public in general, such as staff time, equipment, supplies or facilities, for private gain or personal purposes. (Res. No. R06-07, § 11, 4-3-2007) Sec. 2-222. - Representation of private interests. In keeping with their role as stewards of the public interest, members shall not appear on behalf of the private interests of third parties before any authority, board, committee, commission or proceeding of the unified government, nor shall members of boards, committees or commissions appear before their own bodies or before any authority, board, committee, commission or pro ceeding of the unified government on behalf of the private interests of third parties on matters related to the areas of service of their bodies. (Res. No. R06-07, § 12, 4-3-2007) Sec. 2-223. - Advocacy. Members shall represent the official policies or positions of the commission of the unified government, authorities, boards, commissions or committees to the best of their ability when designated as delegates for this purpose. When presenting their individual opinions and positions, members shall explicitly state they do not represent their body or the Unified Government of Georgetown-Quitman County, nor will they allow the inference that they do. (Res. No. R06-07, § 13, 4-3-2007) Sec. 2-224. - Policy role of members. The Commission of the Unified Government of Georgetown-Quitman County, Georgia determines the policies of the unified government with the advice, information and analysis provided by the public, authorities, boards, commissions, and committees, and unified government staff. The commission of the unified government delegates authority for the administration of the unified government to the manager of the unified government. Members therefore shall not interfere with the administrative functions of the unified government or the professional duties of unified government staff; nor shall they impair the ability of staff to implement the policy decisions of the commission of the unified government. (Res. No. R06-07, § 14, 4-3-2007) Sec. 2-225. - Positive work place environment. Members shall support the maintenance of a positive and constructive work place environment for employees of the unified government and for citizens and businesses dealing with the unified government. Members shall recognize their special role in dealings with employees of the unified government and in no way create the perception of inappropriate direction to staff. (Res. No. R06-07, § 15, 4-3-2007) Sec. 2-226. - Implementation. As an expression of the standards of conduct for members expected by the unified government, the Georgetown-Quitman County Code of Ethics is intended to be self-enforcing. It therefore becomes most effective when members are thoroughly familiar with it and embrace its provisions. For this reason, ethical standards shall be included in the regular orientations for candidates for the commission of the unified government, applicants to authorities, boards, committees and commissions, and newly elected and appointed officials. Members entering office shall sign a statement affirming they have read and understood the Georgetown-Quitman County Code of Ethics. In addition, the commission of the unified government, authorities, boards, committees and commissions, shall annually review the code of ethics and the commission of the unified government shall consider recommendations from boards, committees and commissions to update it as necessary. (Res. No. R06-07, § 16, 4-3-2007) Sec. 2-227. - Compliance and enforcement. The Georgetown-Quitman County Code of Ethics expresses standards of ethical conduct expected of members of the commission of the unified government, authorities, boards, committees and commissions. Members themselves have the primary responsibility to assure that ethical standards are understood and met, and that the public can continue to have full confidence in the integrity of the unified government. The chairs of authorities, boards, committees and commissions and the chair of the commission of the unified government have the additional responsibility to intervene when actions of members that appear to be in violation of the code of ethics are brought to their attention. The commission of the unified government may impose sanctions on members whose conduct does not comply with the unified government's ethical standards, such as reprimand, formal censure, loss of seniority or committee assignment, or budget restriction. Where allowed by law, the Commission of the Unified Government of Georgetown-Quitman County, Georgia also may remove members of appointed authorities, boards, committees and commissions from office. A violation of this code of ethics shall not be considered a basis for challenging the validity of a decision of the commission of the unified government, authority, board, committee or commission. Refusal to sign the member statement will result in the disqualification of an appointee. (Res. No. R06-07, § 17, 4-3-2007) Secs. 2-228—2-250. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - COUNTY VEHICLES, EQUIPMENT; PROPERTY DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-251—2-280. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - COUNTY VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENT USE GUIDELINES
Sec. 2-281. - Use of county vehicles. (a) The employee to whom a Georgetown-Quitman County vehicle is entrusted is responsible for its proper operation and upkeep. Automotive service shall be authorized by supervisors. The employee to whom the vehicle is entrusted is responsible for seeing that servicing is authorized and obtained. (b) County vehicles shall be used only to perform "official county business". Commuting to and from work, where applicable, meal breaks while on duty and to accommodate personal physical needs when such facilities are not available on the job site and like breaks employees may need while attending meetings, conferences, seminars, etc., representing Georgetown-Quitman County shall be considered "official county business. All vehicles will be allocated by the department head or county manager in compliance with this policy. (c) The following restrictions will be adhered to: (1) In order to take home a county vehicle, the individual must be subject to call-back or emergencies and the department head must be sure that this use is justified based on past evidence of their need to be called in outside of their normal shift. (2) Individuals will only be permitted to take a vehicle home if they live within Quitman County. (Ord. No. 01-10, § I, 3-9-10) Sec. 2-282. - Criteria for take home vehicle. (a) Required due to equipment and response need (i.e., K-9 unit, SWAT team, investigators, etc.). (b) Required due to call-backs. (c) Department head or elected officials, who are approved by the board of commissioners. (d) Exceptions: (1) Temporary emergency is justified and approved by the department director or elected official. (2) Upon board approval. (e) Marked police and sheriffs office vehicles within county, the board of commissioners finds that a public safety need is addressed by the presence of marked vehicles within the county. (Ord. No. 01-10, § II, 3-9-10) Sec. 2-283. - Rules for county vehicle use. (a) Drivers are permitted to use the vehicle only for "official county business". Care should be taken to minimize the county's liability at all times. (b) Department heads must maintain documentation to support the need for personnel to have take home vehicles. Lack of this support may result in denial or retraction of permission for vehicle to be taken home. All county vehicles shall be based or housed in Georgetown-Quitman County only. (c) Only county employees, age 18 or over, are permitted to drive a county vehicle (unless the county commission has pulled their approval to operate a county vehicle). (d) There is "no smoking" in county vehicles in accordance with county policy. (e) Employees authorized to take home a county vehicle must provide an "off-street" area at the employee's home to park the vehicle overnight. (f) The driver must possess and maintain a valid driver's license approved for the class appropriate for the vehicle (and provide a copy to the county commission office of such license). (g) The employee is personally responsible for all traffic citations received while driving a county vehicle, such violation must be reported to the department head and county manager promptly and the employee must pay any adjudged fines. (h) The employee must comply with the operator responsibilities, accident reporting requirements and other county procedures. (i) Seat belt. Per Georgia State law, anyone operating or riding in Georgetown-Quitman County vehicles are required wear seat belts at all times. (j) Drivers shall refrain from transporting excessive loads or unsecured luggage, equipment or other moveable items. (k) Drivers must perform a complete walk-around inspection each time they operate a county vehicle, this inspection shall record all vehicle damage as well as check fuel and fluid levels, external lights, signals and tires, and ensure a current insurance card, and first-aid kit, are inside the vehicle at all times. (l) Drivers must participate in a defensive driving course at least once every three years. (m) Drivers must report any accident that involves injuries or damage to the county vehicle, any passengers, to someone else or their property immediately upon returning to the department or work site on the "accident/incident report" and turn the report in to their supervisor. Also, the police should be called to prepare an official report. In addition, the driver should notify their immediate supervisor and a county manager. (n) All drivers should utilize a backup person where available to assist with backing, especially large trucks. Do not depend solely on mirrors; physically look at your surroundings before backing. (o) When driving and operating a cellular telephone, use voice-activated dialing, or have frequently called numbers programmed into the device. (p) Drivers may transport officers, officials, employees, clients, prisoners, detainees, program participants (typically in vans), passengers or guests of the county so long as the purpose is official county business. (q) Drivers may not transport items or cargo having no relation to the conduct of official business. (r) Drivers may not transport acids, explosives, weapons, ammunition, or highly flammable material except in an emergency, law enforcement situation, or performance of an authorized task in the normal scope of duties. (Ord. No. 01-10, § III, 3-9-10) Sec. 2-284. - Penalties for violation of this division. Any employee or person violating any of the provisions of this division shall become liable to the unified government for any expense, loss, damage, fine, penalty or fees occasioned by the unified government, by reason of such violation or violations including, but not limited to, any fee, penalty or fine assessed against the unified government by any state or federal agency as a result of such violation or violations. All unified government officials and employees may face a disciplinary action up to dismissal of employment and/or $100.00/incident fine. (Ord. No. 01-10, § IV, 3-9-10)

div.head: Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 02-14, adopted Oct. 14, 2014, amended ch. 6 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former ch. 6, §§ 6-1—6-195, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from: Res. of Jan. 1, 1999, §§ 1-1—1-13, 1-15, 1-16, 2-1—2-23, 3-1(a)—(f), 4-1—4-4, 5-1—5-7 and art. I; Ord. of Jan. 8, 2008; Ord. No. 02-09, adopted Mar. 10, 2009; Ord. No. 10-08, adopted Apr. 13, 2010; and Ord. No. 10-08A, §§ 1—3, adopted Oct. 11, 2011. Cross reference— Abuse of alcohol and controlled substances, § 34-31 et seq. State Law reference— Alcoholic beverages generally, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; local alcoholic beverage licenses, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2 et seq.; local regulation of distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-40 et seq.; local regulation of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-40 et seq.; local regulation of wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-40; public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41.
ARTICLE I. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE CONTROL
Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Alcohol means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, or spirits of wine, from whatever source or by whatever process produced. Alcoholic beverage means and includes all alcohol, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverage, wine or fortified wine. Applicant means any one or more persons making application for a Georgetown-Quitman County or state for alcoholic beverage license of any type or renewal thereof. Application means those forms, statements and applications authorized or required under the terms and conditions of this chapter, other applicable laws and regulations of Georgetown-Quitman County and those applicable requirements of the state. Church shall include synagogue, and any other place of permanent public religious worship which shall exist if a valid building permit has been obtained and substantial construction is underway. College, school means those state, county, city, church or other colleges or schools teaching the subjects common in schools or colleges of the state. County clerk means the Clerk of the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County. Due cause means cause for suspension, revocation, cancellation or denial of any alcoholic beverage license which shall consist of any violation of this chapter or any laws or ordinances of Georgetown-Quitman County or state, prohibiting or regulating the business of selling, transporting or dealing in alcoholic beverages or violation of ordinances, laws or regulations made pursuant to authority granted for the purpose of regulation of such businesses; or for the violation of any Georgetown-Quitman County, state or federal law involving moral turpitude, controlled substances or violation of Georgetown-Quitman County ordinances other than traffic ordinances. It shall also consist of willfully false statements or conduct of applicant for an alcoholic beverage license or renewal thereof or willful concealment of material matters of fact of obtaining or preventing another from obtaining a license hereunder. Immediate family or member of immediate family means all persons related to each other by consanguinity or affinity within the first degree, as computed according to the civil law. Inspector or license inspector means that person designated as license inspector of Georgetown-Quitman County and his representatives. Interest or financial interest means a pecuniary interest and shall include any present or future, whole or partial, legal or beneficial, direct or indirect, right, power or authority or control of or in any Class I, Class II, Class III, Class IV or Class V alcoholic beverage application for license and/or license issued; it shall apply to the outright owner, co-owner, member of a partnership, or stockholder in a corporation, organized or in the process of organizing, for pecuniary gain, which owns or is to own any financial interest in any class of alcoholic beverage application and/or license issued for any class of such license within the limits of Georgetown-Quitman County and shall include any such interest in the premises from which such alcoholic beverages are sold. If any of the income from the sales of alcoholic beverages is shared, or rent, lease, etc., on which land is, or is to be paid on the basis of sales of alcoholic beverages on such land, and anyone sharing in any income or corpus of any trust fund or estate having any interest in such applications, licenses or premises shall have a financial interest therein. Also, it shall include a lender of money or other thing of value to such applicant or licensee, to anyone else for the benefit of such applicant or licensee, on interest in excess of the highest level rate allowable in this state. License means a license granted by Georgetown-Quitman County and/or state, granted or issued upon the basis of the alleged truth of a written application therefore to sell alcoholic beverages of any kind or nature within Georgetown-Quitman County. License year means that 12-month period for and with respect to which licenses under this chapter shall be issued. Such license year shall commence on January 1 of each year and end at midnight on the December 31 next following. Licensee means that person duly licensed or having interest therein as licensed, by Georgetown-Quitman County to distribute, transport, sell at wholesale, retail or by the drink, alcoholic beverages of any kind or nature within Georgetown-Quitman County. Malt beverage means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops or any other similar product, or any combination of such products in water, containing not more than six percent alcohol by volume and including ale, porter, brown, stout, lager beer, small beer, and strong beer. The term does not include sake, known as Japanese rice wine. Manufacturer means any maker, producer or bottler of an alcoholic beverage. The term also means: (1) In the case of malt beverages, any brewer. (2) In the case of wine, any vintner. Minor means any person under 21 years of age. Off-premises sales of alcoholic beverages means the sale of alcoholic beverages of any kind or nature, kind or class in sealed, unbroken containers for consumption not on the premises of the licensee. On-premises sales of alcoholic beverages means the sale, giving or dispensing of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises of the licensee. Original/initial, when used in connection with an application for an alcoholic beverage license, means the first license granted for a given location or first use or application for use or change of use of a given application for use of a location previously licensed or approved for a license hereunder. Package means a bottle, can, keg, barrel or other original consumer container. Park means property utilized for passive and/or active recreational use by the public. Premises means those lots, plots or tracts of land upon which any structure, building, store, mobile trailer, etc., is located from which alcoholic beverages are sold, dispensed, stored, consumed or given to the public including, but not limited to, that building, structure, room or closed or partitioned-in locality whether a room, shop, structure or building wherein alcoholic beverages are sold, dispensed, stored, consumed or given to the public. Private dwelling means a house or dwelling or structure wherein one or more persons reside at the time of the filing of an application under this chapter. Renewal, when used in connection with an application for a license or a location, means an unrevoked alcoholic beverage license issued hereunder to a designated licensee for a designated location, on expiration of which unrevoked license the identical owners thereof, but no others, may be entitled to a new annual license for the same, but no other location. Residence means domicile. Restaurant means any public place kept, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are served and where meals are actually and regularly served, without sleeping accommodations, such place being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen, bathrooms and dining room equipment and seating capacity of at least 50 people, having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its guests. Serving of such meals shall be the principal business conducted, with the serving of alcoholic beverages to be consumed on the premises as only incidental thereto. No alcoholic beverages shall be sold or served unless regular meals are also being served with the alcoholic beverages. No brown bagging or "bring your own" shall be allowed. No premises shall be considered to be a restaurant if there is a distinct room set up as primarily as a drinking area rather than an eating area such that there appears to be a restaurant area and a "bar" area. To qualify as a restaurant and an eating establishment under this section, such establishment must derive at least 60 percent of its total annual gross sales of food and beverage from the sales of prepared meals and foods. A restaurant shall have a general liability policy from an insurer licensed to do business in the State of Georgia in the amount of $2,000,000.00. Satisfactory proof means adequate or sufficient evidence to convince an unbiased, impartial, enlightened judge of the existence or nonexistence of a fact, situation or condition. Store means a room or area wherein only the sale at retail of alcoholic beverages in the original unbroken packages, bottles, containers, etc., may be authorized under this chapter and the Revenue Tax Act to legalize and control alcoholic beverages. Wholesale distributor of alcoholic beverages means that license issued by Georgetown-Quitman County enabling the licensee to distribute, sell, offer to sell to a bona fide Class II, Class III, Class IV or Class V license holder, at wholesale prices, alcoholic beverages in unbroken packages or containers. Wine means any alcoholic beverage containing not more than 21 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries or grapes either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. The term includes, but is not limited to, all sparkling wines, champagnes, combinations of such beverages, vermouths, special natural wines, rectified wines, and like products. The term does not include cooking wine mixed with salt or other ingredients so as to render it unfit for human consumption as a beverage. A liquid shall first be deemed to be a wine at that point in the manufacturing process when it conforms to the definition of wine contained in this section. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 6-2. - License constitutes grant or privilege. (a) All licenses shall be a mere grant or privilege to carry on such business during the term of the license subject to all the terms and conditions imposed by this division and related laws, and other ordinances and resolutions of the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County relating to such business. (b) The distributing, selling, handling, and otherwise dealing in or possessing alcoholic beverages are declared to be privileges within the boundaries of the Georgetown-Quitman County and not rights; however, such privileges shall not be exercised except in accordance with the licensing and regulatory requirements of this chapter. (c) All licenses shall be and shall have printed on the front these words: "This license is a mere privilege subject to be suspended, revoked, canceled or annulled by the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County, and is subject to any future ordinances enacted by Georgetown-Quitman County, Georgia." (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-3. - Penalty for violation of chapter. The violation of the terms and conditions of this chapter by any applicant, licensee, his manager, director, operator, agents, assigns or employees for which such applicant and/or licensee is deemed responsible shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00 and/or imprisonment in the county jail for a period not to exceed ten days in the discretion of the court and shall be subject to sections 6-166 and 6-167. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-4. - Illegal acts on licensed premises. No holder of a license authorizing the sale of alcoholic beverages within Georgetown-Quitman County, nor any agent, representative or employee of such licensee, shall perform any of the acts following which are hereby declared illegal: (1) Sell alcoholic beverages to a minor. (2) Sell alcoholic beverages to any person while such person is in an intoxicated condition. (3) Sell alcoholic beverages upon the licensed premises or permit consumption thereon, on any day or at any time when such sales or consumption is prohibited by law. (4) Permit on the licensed premises any disorderly conduct; breach of peace; or any lewd, immoral, improper entertainment, conduct or practices. (5) Dispense in any way to minors. It shall be unlawful for the licensee to sell, attempt to sell, give, distribute or dispense alcoholic beverages to a minor. (6) Purchase for minor. It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase alcoholic beverages on behalf of a minor. (7) Possession by minor. It shall be unlawful for any minor to have in his possession, care or custody any alcoholic beverage. (8) Spurious credentials. It shall be unlawful for any minor to exhibit fake, forged, borrowed or otherwise illegal credentials in an effort to obtain alcoholic beverages in any manner to which he is not legally entitled. (9) Acquiesce, permit or allow, the bringing into, use of, sale, possession, dispensing, storing or in any other manner condone the presence of controlled substances/illicit drugs, narcotics, cocaine, crack, marijuana or any other substances declared illegal by Georgetown-Quitman County, state or U.S. Government. Failure of the owner, operator, manager, representative, agents or employees of same to insure compliance with this section shall, within 24 hours of such finding by the governing body, the state or the U.S. Government, result in immediate revocation of the alcoholic beverage license and closing of the business so licensed. (10) Permit or allow any person to bring into licensees' place of business any form of alcoholic beverages and/or consume the alcoholic beverages brought into the licensed premises. The intent and purpose of this prohibition is to prohibit what is commonly referred to as brown bagging. All violations of this section are, in addition to the above, subject to all penalties provided for in this chapter and/or ordinances, laws, regulations of Georgetown-Quitman County, state and U.S. Government. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) State Law reference— Furnishing to, purchase of, or possession by persons under 21 years of age of alcoholic beverages; use of false identification; proper identification for sale of alcoholic beverages; dispensing, serving, etc., of alcoholic beverages by persons under 21 years of age in the course of employment; seller's duty to request proper identification, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23; public indecency, O.C.G.A. § 16-6-8; prohibited conduct on licensed premises, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-40 et seq.; age of legal majority, O.C.G.A. § 39-1-1. Sec. 6-5. - Enforcement personnel; right of entry. The Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County, or its designee, the Sheriff of Quitman County, or his or her designee, as well as those personnel of the alcoholic beverage enforcement division of the state, and of the U.S. Government, are hereby authorized to enter into or upon the premises of any class of alcoholic beverage licensed location at any time the enforcement agencies herein noted deem necessary in the enforcement of this chapter or other Georgetown-Quitman County, state or U.S. Government, laws, ordinances, rules or regulations. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-6. - Sale to minors, intoxicated or incompetent persons. No licensee shall give, sell, offer to sell, dispense or otherwise permit the same to any person under 21 years of age or those otherwise defined as minors under the laws of the state or to anyone who is noticeably intoxicated, or who is of unsound mind. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-7. - Employment of persons under 18 years of age. (a) No person shall allow or require a person in his employment under 18 years of age to dispense, serve, sell or take orders for any alcoholic beverages. (b) This section shall not prohibit persons under 18 years of age who are employed in supermarkets, markets, convenience stores, gas stations, or drugstores from selling or handling alcoholic beverages which are sold for consumption off the premises. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-8. - Days, hours of sale. No person shall sell, offer for sale, give, dispense or distribute alcoholic beverages at the following times: (1) Class II and Class III licenses from 12:59 a. m. to 11:30 a.m. on Sunday. (2) Class IV and Class V licenses (consumption on-premises) from 12:59 a.m. 11:30 a.m. each day. (3) At any time prohibited by state or federal law. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14; Ord. No. 04-15 , § 1, 8-11-15; Ord. No. 04-17 , 12-12-17) Sec. 6-9. - Closing, clearing of premises. All owners, managers, operators, representatives, agents or employees of a holder of a Class II, Class III, Class IV or Class V alcoholic beverage license shall cease the sales, offer to sell, give, dispense, or distribute any alcoholic beverages on or from the premises for which a Class IV or Class V license has been issued by Georgetown-Quitman County and/or the state as of 11:55 p.m. of each day of the week on which sales are not prohibited in section 6-8, and shall require all patrons or parties to vacate the premises from which a Class IV or Class V alcoholic beverage license has been issued by 12:00 a.m. (midnight). (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-10. - Penalty for sales during closed days and hours. Violation of sections 6-6, 6-7, 6-8 or 6-9 shall result in due cause for revocation of any and all alcoholic beverage licenses held by the owner, lessee or renter of the premises found in violation hereof and shall subject same to all penalties contained in this chapter. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-11. - Display of license. The license under this chapter shall at all times be kept plainly exposed to view at the place of business of the licensee. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-12. - Sales in licensed premises only. No alcoholic beverage licensee shall sell or deliver any alcoholic beverage to any person except in the licensee's place of business. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-13. - Means and places of receipt of delivery to retail licensee; place of sale. Alcoholic beverages shall be received at or delivered to the premises of the retail licensee by no means other than conveyance owned and operated by a wholesale dealer with a permit from the governing body to make deliveries in Georgetown-Quitman County. Transportation of alcoholic beverages by any other means shall be grounds for revocation of a retail license and/or wholesale permit. No retail sales or deliveries of alcoholic beverages shall be made except in the place of business in which such sales and deliveries are authorized. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-14. - Licensee identification signs. Each person licensed to sell alcoholic beverages at retail shall have printed or plainly painted on the front window of the licensed premises the full legal name of the licensee, together with the inscription of his correct Georgetown-Quitman County license number inserted in the blank space therefore, e.g., "Georgetown-Quitman County Retail License No. 07" in uniform letters not less than four inches in height; provided, if a licensee desires, he may have his full and correct legal name displayed on the inside of the front window in neon or other electric lights. Such sign shall be parallel with the window and so constructed as not to extend more than six inches from the window. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-15. - Display of prices and/or penal sections generally. Each Class II and Class III licensee shall have conspicuously displayed within the interior of the licensed premises not less than four copies of the printed price list of the alcoholic beverages offered for sale and printed copy of the penal sections of this chapter; provided, however, that a licensee, in lieu of having four copies of a printed price list may have the prices of the alcoholic beverages offered for sale located and placed on the bottles, or on the bottom of the shelf directly under such bottles wherein such alcoholic beverages are exhibited for sale. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-16. - Outside display of prices prohibited. No sign advertising any brand or price of alcoholic beverages shall be permitted on the exterior of any licensed premises, and no placard or sign visible from the exterior of the licensed premises shall refer to the price of any alcoholic beverages for sale therein. Any interior window signs shall be discreet and shall not reflect the price of any alcoholic beverage. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-17. - Interior visibility, Class IV or Class V license. No screen, blind, curtain, partition, article or thing shall be permitted in the window or upon the doors of a Class IV and Class V licenses licensed premises which shall prevent a clear view into the interior of such premises from the street or road at all times and no booths, screen, partition or other obstruction shall be permitted within the interior of such licensed premises that blocks such view which shall plainly permit visibility from the street or road day and night. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-18. - Interior light switch, proximity to front door, Class IV and Class V license. There shall be installed and maintained within 24 inches of the front door of all Class IV or Class V on-premises licensed establishments and not more than five feet from the floor, a single light switch that will actuate, but not deactivate, without a key thereto, all interior lighting of the licensed establishment. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-19. - Front entrance location, Class IV or Class V license. No license shall be granted for Class IV or Class V alcoholic beverage sales hereunder unless the front entrance to the premises is clearly visible from a public street, and the premises around the building of the licensee shall be on all corners thereof, lit with a minimum of 250-watt high pressure sodium lighting. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-20. - Gambling devices, slot machines, etc. Within the premises of a Class II, Class III, Class IV or Class V license holder there shall be no illegal gambling or in any room adjoining the same, owned, leased or controlled by licensee. Any violation of this section shall be cause for suspension or revocation of the license. Nothing contained herein shall restrict the presence of amusement games and/or video machine games or the Georgia Lottery within the premises of a Class II, Class III, Class IV or Class V license holder. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-21. - Sales in central business district. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, distribute or otherwise dispense of any alcoholic beverage within the central business district area unless the person holds a Class IV and Class V license under this chapter for a restaurant. For purposes of this chapter, the central business district area is defined as that area within 1,000 feet of the Quitman County Courthouse. Sec. 6-22. - Possession or consumption of an open container in public place. It shall be unlawful for any person to drink or to attempt to drink any alcoholic, malt or vinous liquors or any intoxicant from a can, bottle or glass or any other container or to possess an opened can, bottle, glass or other container containing any alcoholic, malt or vinous liquor or any intoxicant on the streets, sidewalks, rights-of-way or designated public parking areas, on the premises of any registered business with the Unified Government of Georgetown-Quitman County, within the corporate limits of the Unified Government of Georgetown-Quitman County. All Class IV and Class V alcohol licensees are exempt from this provision on licensed premises. All state laws concerning open container in vehicles shall be adhered to. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-23. - Location for the sale of alcohol. (a) Class II, Class III, Class IV or Class V license premises must be located in a C-1 (commercial zone) zoning district. (b) In addition to being located in a C-1 (commercial zone) zoning district, Class III license premises must be located on a tract or parcel of land that adjoins and abuts U.S. Route 82. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Secs. 6-24—6-45. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - LICENSES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 6-46. - Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, sell or possess for the purpose of sale any alcoholic beverages where such person does not have a license from Georgetown-Quitman County to sell or possess for sale such beverages. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-47. - Compliance with all applicable provisions. No alcoholic beverage license shall be issued to the premises of an applicant that does not comply with all codes, ordinances and laws of the state and of Georgetown-Quitman County, whether it is an initial license, renewal or transfer of applicant or location. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) State Law reference— Permit or license from county or municipality required for wholesale or retail sales of alcoholic beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2; powers of local governing authorities as to the granting, refusal, suspension or revocation of alcoholic beverage permits or licenses, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2. Sec. 6-48. - Classification. (a) All alcoholic beverage licenses shall henceforth be classified as follows: (1) Class I license means that license granted to any person by Georgetown-Quitman County to an applicant for the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages sold at wholesale to any valid alcoholic beverage licensee. (2) Class II license means that license granted to any persons by Georgetown-Quitman County to an applicant for package sales of wine and malt beverages sold at retail to the public for consumption off the premises. (3) Class III license means that license granted to any persons by Georgetown-Quitman County to an applicant for package sales of distilled spirits sold at retail to the public for consumption off the premises. (4) Class IV license means that license granted to any person by Georgetown-Quitman County to an applicant for an on-premises beer and wine consumption license at a location that meets the definition of a restaurant under this chapter. (5) Class V license means that license granted to any person by Georgetown-Quitman County to an applicant for an on-premises distilled spirits consumption license at a location that meets the definition of a restaurant under this chapter. (b) All applications and licenses issued hereafter shall be in keeping with the above classifications. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-49. - Separate licenses required. A separate alcoholic beverage license is hereby required for each place of business when such application includes various classes of licenses (Class I, II, III, IV, V). (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-50. - Georgetown-Quitman County to maintain files. Georgetown-Quitman County shall endeavor to accumulate and maintain a complete file of licenses granted under the terms and conditions of this chapter. Such file may contain any information deemed appropriate by the Georgetown-Quitman County, and may include applications, investigative reports, licenses issued, incidents involving licensee and/or place of business, code and/or building violations, hearings/results, premises inspections, photographs and other such information and data that may assist Georgetown-Quitman County in the determination of the decision to grant, renew, transfer, name change or other license actions required and/or applied for within Georgetown-Quitman County. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Secs. 6-51—6-65. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - APPLICATION
Sec. 6-66. - General prerequisites for approval. No pending or future application for a Georgetown-Quitman County alcoholic beverage license shall be approved by Georgetown-Quitman County unless it appears that all material and valid requirements of this chapter have been met by the applicant and that the applicant is qualified to hold a license, should it be issued, under this chapter. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-67. - New license, approval required. No new alcoholic beverage license shall be issued until first having received approval of the license application by the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-68. - Procedure. All applicants for an alcoholic beverage license shall comply with the following application procedure: (1) All applications for an alcoholic beverage license shall be submitted on forms provided for that purpose by Georgetown-Quitman County Clerk and shall be approved by the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County prior to the issuance of the license applied for. (2) The application shall include but shall not be limited to: the name and address of the applicant; the proposed business to be carried on; if a partnership, the names and residence address of the partners; if a limited liability company, L.L.C., the name and address of the manager(s) and the name of any person or legal entity owning any percentage of the L.L.C.; if a corporation, the names of the officers, the name and address of the registered agent for service of process, the name of the officer(s), and the name of all shareholders of any class of corporate stock, or any other entity having a financial interest in each entity which is to own or operate the establishment for which a license is sought. If the manager changes, the applicant must furnish the commission the name and address of the new manager and other information as requested within ten days of such change. (3) All applicants shall furnish data, fingerprints, financial responsibility and other records as required by the licensing and revenue manager and to ensure compliance with the provisions of this article. Failure to furnish data, pursuant to such request shall automatically serve to dismiss the application with prejudice. (4) All applications shall be sworn to by the applicant before a notary public or other officer empowered by law to administer oaths as to the information contained in the application and to any other information required or contained within the application and accompanying information and by this chapter. (5) In all instances in which an application is denied under the provisions of this chapter the applicant may not reapply for a license for at least one year from the final date of such denial. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-69. - Minimum applicant qualifications. Any applicant for an alcoholic beverage license shall meet the minimum qualifications upon the submission of an application for same, as follows: (1) Be 21 years of age. (2) Meet all minimum requirements for such license imposed by the state. (3) No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be granted to any person who is not a citizen of the United States or an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence. (4) Where the applicant is a partnership, limited liability company or corporation, the provisions of this section shall apply to all its partners, officers, manager(s) and stockholders. In the case of a corporation the license shall be issued jointly to the corporation and a stockholder, if an individual. Where the majority stockholder is not an individual, the license shall be issued jointly to the corporation and its agent registered under the provisions of this chapter. In the case of a partnership the license will be issued to all the partners. In the case of a limited liability company, the license will be issued jointly to the limited liability company and manager(s). (5) The license applicant and all employees thereof shall not have been convicted within ten years of the date of application of any felony, misdemeanor, excepting minor traffic violations, or any violations of the laws or ordinances of Georgetown-Quitman County, state or United States relating to the distribution, sale or dispensing of alcoholic beverages or any crime involving moral turpitude. A plea of nolo contendere for any felony or misdemeanor of any city, state or federal court, or a forfeiture of a bond when charged with a crime is hereby considered a conviction under this chapter; provided, however, where the violation is for a misdemeanor or the forfeiture of bond involves a municipal ordinance, Georgetown-Quitman County in its discretion may waive such disqualification. (6) No person, firm limited liability company or corporation shall be granted any alcoholic beverage license unless it shall appear to the satisfaction of the commission, or its designee, that such person, manager(s), partners in the firm, or officers and directors of the corporation have not been convicted or plead guilty or entered a plea of nolo contendere to, and have been released from parole or probation concerning any crime involving moral turpitude, illegal gambling or illegal possession or sale of controlled substances or the illegal possession or sale of alcoholic beverages, including the sale or transfer of alcoholic beverages to minors in a manner contrary to law, keeping a place of prostitution, pandering, pimping, public indecency, prostitution, solicitation of sodomy, or any sexual related crime within a period of ten years immediately prior to the filing of such application. At the time an application is submitted for any alcoholic beverage license, the applicant shall, by a duly sworn affidavit, certify that neither the applicant, nor any of the other owners of the establishment has been convicted or has pleaded guilty or entered a plea of nolo contendere to any crime involving moral turpitude, illegal gambling or illegal possession or sale of controlled substances or the illegal possession or sale of alcoholic beverages, including the sale or transfer of alcoholic beverages to minors in a manner contrary to law, keeping a place of prostitution, pandering, pimping, public indecency, prostitution, solicitation of sodomy, or any sexual-related crime within a period of ten years immediately prior to the filing of such application. Should any applicant, partner, or officer instrumental in the sale or dispensing of any alcoholic beverage, after a license has been granted, be convicted or plead guilty or nolo contendere to a crime involving moral turpitude, illegal gambling or illegal possession or sale of controlled substances or the illegal possession or sale of alcoholic beverages, including the sale or transfer of alcoholic beverages to minors in a manner contrary to law, keeping a place of prostitution, pandering, pimping, public indecency, prostitution, solicitation of sodomy, or any sexual-related crime, the license shall be immediately revoked and cancelled. (7) No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be granted to any person convicted under any federal, state or local law of any felony, within ten years prior to the filing of application for such license. (8) It shall be unlawful for any county employee directly involved in the issuance of alcoholic beverage licenses under this chapter, to have any whole, partial or beneficial interest in any license to sell alcoholic beverages in the county. (9) No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be granted to any person who has had any license issued under the police powers of the county previously revoked within two years prior to the filing of the application. (10) The commission may decline to issue a license when any person having any ownership interest in the operation of such place of business or control over such place of business does not meet the same character requirements as herein set forth for the licensee. (11) All licensed establishments must have and continuously maintain in the county a registered agent upon whom any process, notice or demand required or permitted by law or under this chapter to be served upon the licensee or owner may be served. This person must be a resident of Georgetown-Quitman County. The licensee shall file the name of such agent, along with the written consent of such agent with the commission and shall be in such form as may be prescribed by the commission. (12) All applicants for any alcoholic beverage license must be of good character, and all operators, managers, clerks, or other employees shall be of like character. Corporate or firm applicants shall be of good business reputation. (13) A license application may be denied to any applicant for any alcoholic beverage license where it appears that the applicant would not have adequate financial participation in the proposed business to direct and manage its affairs, or where it appears that the application is intended to be a mere surrogate for a person or persons who would not otherwise qualify for a license for any reason whatsoever. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-70. - Statement of qualifications by applicant. The applicant shall make a sworn statement of his qualifications according to the terms and conditions of this chapter, and shall file same with the manager of Georgetown-Quitman County prior to any approval of application or license issuance. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-71. - Misstatement, concealment of fact. Any misstatement or concealment of fact by the applicant shall be grounds for revocation of license issued and shall make the applicant liable to prosecution for perjury under the laws or ordinances of Georgetown-Quitman County, state and/or United States Government. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-72. - Reserved. Sec. 6-73. - Delegation of management. If the applicant/licensee for an alcoholic beverage license shall assign, allow, direct or permit the management, operations or conduct of the alcoholic beverage business by a party or parties other than himself, the party and/or parties managing, directing, conducting or operating such business shall be deemed equally responsible and subject to all conditions of this chapter in every respect in the same manner and degree as the owner. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-74. - Duties of manager, operator or designee. (a) The manager, operator or designee shall be that person designated by the licensee as responsible for the management and/or conduct of business connected with the operation of a licensed alcoholic beverage establishment, Class I, Class II, Class III, Class IV or Class V. The manager, operator or designee shall devote and be on the premises of the licensee a minimum of 30 hours per work week and shall be subject to the terms and conditions of this chapter. (b) It shall be the responsibility of the alcoholic beverage licensee to notify the Georgetown-Quitman County Manager within 48 hours in writing of any change made by the licensee in the manager, operator or designee for the operation of the licensed premises. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-75. - Georgetown-Quitman County's right of rejection of manager, designee; investigation; notice. Georgetown-Quitman County shall have the right to accept or reject such manager, operator and/or designee based upon the results of an investigation of the record of the individual. The licensee shall be notified, in writing, by the Georgetown-Quitman County Manager as to the results of such investigation within 72 hours of such determination. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-76. - Fingerprinting and investigation—Applicants. All applicants for an alcoholic beverage license within Georgetown-Quitman County shall be fingerprinted in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2 which same shall be submitted to the Georgia Bureau of Investigation in accordance with said law, who in turn shall submit same to the FBI and a record shall be returned to Georgetown-Quitman County as provided for by said statute. Georgetown-Quitman County shall have the right to issue or reject such application based solely upon the results of the investigation. No license shall be issued without said report. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-77. - Additional information. The applicant shall furnish such other information as the Georgetown-Quitman County Manager may, upon direction of the commission, from time to time require. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-78. - Agreement to pay taxes. The applicant shall sign an agreement that, in consideration of the privilege of approval of the application/license, the applicant shall pay all taxes, fees, levies, etc., imposed upon the licensee by this chapter and will sell or hold for sale no alcoholic beverage upon which such taxes, fees, levies, etc., have not been paid. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-79. - Public hearing required. All applicants for a new alcoholic beverage license within Georgetown-Quitman County shall be required to have a public hearing conducted by the commission prior to the issuance of such license. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Secs. 6-80—6-95. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - FEES
Sec. 6-96. - Original investigative fee. All applicants for an initial alcoholic beverage license shall, at the time of application therefore, deposit with the Manager of Georgetown-Quitman County a nonrefundable investigation fee as set by the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-97. - License fees. All applicants for an initial alcohol beverage license shall deposit with the Manager of Georgetown-Quitman County a license fee for such license as set by the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County. Generally, no such fees shall be prorated for any portion of a year, nor shall any such fees be refundable, unless said fees are refundable under section 6-119. Provided however, the commission may prorate fees for a portion of the year if the circumstances call for such proration as determined in the sole discretion of the commission. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-98. - Renewal. (a) The annual license fee for the renewal of an alcoholic beverage license once granted shall be as set by the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County. (b) All licenses for the upcoming year must be purchased prior to December 31 of each year. Licenses expire at midnight December 31. Renewing applicants are required to be fingerprinted and pay an administration fee of $100.00 annually at renewal time. (c) Upon application for a renewal of an alcoholic beverage license for a restaurant (Class IV and Class V licenses), a sales statement must be submitted by the license holder and the management of the establishment showing the total sales of food and alcoholic beverages and the percentage of food sales. In addition, the license holder shall submit a statement from each wholesaler from whom the licensee has purchased any type of alcohol which said statement must show the total dollar amount of alcohol beverages sold to the license holder for the license year. Georgetown-Quitman County may cause an audit of the books of a licensee to be made at any time. Each license holder, by virtue of having applied for a license, shall furnish to Georgetown-Quitman County all books and records when requested by Georgetown-Quitman County. Failure of a licensee to furnish the books and records and to cooperate in the execution of the audit shall be a violation of this chapter. An applicant shall, with the application for a Class IV and Class V licenses license, submit a projected sales statement showing the percentage of food and alcohol sales anticipated. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14; Amend. of 10-13-16 ) Sec. 6-99. - Beer and wine background check administration fee. All beer and wine applicants and distilled spirits applicants that are renewing are required to pay an administration fee of $100.00 at renewal time. All first time alcoholic beverage license applicants are required to be fingerprinted and pay $255.00 for administration fee. (Ord. No. 05-2016, 10-13-16; Amend. of 10-13-16 ) Secs. 6-100—6-110. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - LOCATION AND BUILDING REQUIREMENTS
Sec. 6-111. - Minimum specifications for retail outlets. All retail sales locations must meet the following minimum specifications: (1) Must meet the building codes adopted by Georgetown-Quitman County. (2) The interior of the building must be clearly visible from the exterior. (3) The interior must contain lighting of such strength that the interior of the building can be clearly seen from the exterior. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-112. - Drawing of premises to accompany application. No application for an alcoholic beverage license shall be approved which does not include or have attached thereto a drawing of the premises and interior and the location at which applicant desires to operate. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-113. - Distance to churches, schools, libraries, etc. No alcoholic beverage license shall be granted or issued to any applicant for such license nor shall alcoholic beverages be sold, offered for sale, given or distributed from the premises of the licensee within the following distance, of: (1) Churches: within 100 yards of any church building. The term "church building" as used herein shall mean the main structure used by any religious organization for purposes of worship. (2) Schools: a. Distilled spirits: within 200 yards of any school building, school grounds or college campus. b. Wine and malt beverages: within 100 yards of any school building, school grounds or college campus. c. As used in this section, the term "school building", "school", "school grounds" or educational building" shall apply only to state, county, city, or church school buildings and to such buildings at such other schools in which are taught subjects commonly taught in the common schools, universities and colleges of this state and which are public schools or private schools as defined in O.C.G.A. § 20-2-690(b). The term "school building" and "educational building" includes only those structures in which instruction is offered. The term "school grounds" and "college campus" shall apply only to the parcel or parcels of land on which a school, school building or educational building is located. The term "college" shall mean an educational institution authorized by the state to award associate, baccalaureate or higher degrees. (3) Libraries and/or branch libraries: within 100 yards feet of any library or branch premises thereof. (4) Alcohol or drug treatment or counseling facility: within 100 yards. (5) Government buildings (except as provided in section 6-21 for the central business district), public parks, recreation centers, sports or athletic facilities: within 100 yards. (6) Any area where minors congregate: within 100 yards. (7) Any private dwelling: within 100 feet. (8) Class III license applications only: within 500 yards of any other business licensed to sell package liquor at retail. (9) No location which is licensed to sell alcoholic beverages on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives shall be denied continued operation under an existing license, or denied any renewal of such license, nor shall any new owner of said location be denied a new license based upon the measurements set forth in this section. (10) As to any location licensed in the future, if the distance requirements herein are met at the time of issuance of any license, the subsequent opening and operation of a church, school, or college within the distance prohibited herein shall not prevent the continuance of an existing license or the renewal thereof or the issuance of a new license to any subsequent owner of such property. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-114. - Distance measurements. (a) Unless otherwise provided by law, those distance measurement prohibitions stated in section 6-113 shall be measured by the most direct route of travel on the ground and shall be measured in the following manner: (1) In a straight line from the front door of the structure from which beverage alcohol is sold or offered for sale; (2) To the front door of the building of a church, government owned treatment center or a Class III retail package store; or (3) To the nearest property line of the real property being used for school or educational purposes. (b) All applications shall include a drawing showing that the premises is not in violation of distances under this chapter and describing the way said distances were measured. At their sole discretion, the commission may require that the applicant furnish a survey conducted by a certified surveyor showing that the premises is in compliance with the distances under this chapter. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) State Law reference— Sales of alcoholic beverages near churches, schools or college campuses, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21. Sec. 6-115. - Issuance during construction. When the license applied for under this article is for a license to be located in a building not in existence when such license application is filed or construction of such building has been commenced, but is not yet completed, a license may, if otherwise authorized hereunder, be issued for such location if the application for such license and the plans for the proposed building clearly show that such building and the distance requirements will, when completed, meet all requirements of this chapter, Georgetown-Quitman County law and the state law. The annual license fee shall not be discounted or reduced for time consumed in building operations after the license is approved, but no sales shall be made at such location until the building has been completed in accordance with the plans and conforms with all provisions of the law and this chapter. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-116. - Distance exception. The measurements indicated in section 6-113 as measured under section 6-114 shall not apply to any person who now holds a license if the measurement was made, at the time the license was originally issued, utilizing some other measuring method. Distance requirements shall also not apply to a Class II license where the business is a grocery store or supermarket. As used in this paragraph, the term "grocery store" or "supermarket" means a retail establishment which has at least 85 percent of its total retail floor space reserved for the sale of food and other nonalcoholic items, conducts all of its sales inside the building containing its retail floor space, where groceries and food are purchased for off the premises consumption and the total sales area of such business exceeds 15,000 square feet. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-117. - Requirements, Class IV and Class V licenses. In addition to all other requirements, no Class IV and Class V licenses shall be issued to any applicant whose business does not meet the definition of a restaurant as herein defined. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-118. - Priority of applicants. (a) Applications must be filed and license fees and administration fees paid in person at the commission offices. Applications will be given priority by the date of filling, provided however, if the number of applicants is more than or equal to the number of licenses available (e.g., when two or more Class III license applications are for premises within 500 yards of another) applications filed within five business days of the initial application will proceed to approval under this chapter. (b) A substantially incomplete or inaccurate application may not be accepted and if accepted and subsequently determined to be substantially incomplete or an inaccurate will likely make the applicant ineligible for being given priority. (c) If there are more approved applicants than licenses available, a public drawing will be held; the time, date and place of any drawing will be posted at the commission offices and the approved applicants will be notified. The drawing will be conducted in a manner the commission deems appropriate. (d) The license fee, will be automatically refunded to each unsuccessful drawing participant. Refund checks will be mailed within 45 days of the priority drawing. The administration fee is nonrefundable. (e) Unsuccessful drawing participants will maintain the priority position assigned at the priority drawing. In the event a successful applicant is disqualified for a license by the State of Georgia or withdraws, the next drawing participant in order of priority will be contacted and will have 30 days to repay the previously refunded license fee, and certify that the information on the original application has not changed. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Secs. 6-119—6-130. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - PUBLIC HEARING
Sec. 6-131. - Required; when. (a) A public hearing shall be conducted by the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County upon the application(s) for any initial alcoholic beverage license. (b) No application for an alcoholic beverage license, except application for renewal thereof, shall be approved or granted by the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County until after a public hearing has been held thereon by the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County after due publication of notice. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-132. - Publication of notice of application and hearing. Prior notice of the public hearing shall be given for three consecutive weeks in the legal organ. Publication expense shall be paid by the applicant in advance and is nonrefundable. The published notice shall include the notice of application; time, date and place of public hearing before the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County as well as any other information required by Georgetown-Quitman County. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-133. - Publication requirements. The publication of a notice of public hearing contained in section 6-132 above shall be made as follows: (1) For the three consecutive weeks immediately prior to the hearing date. (2) No such notice of publication required herein shall be less than ten-point capital and lower case lettering with a minimum of one-inch, two-column size. (Ord. No. 02-14, 10-14-14) Sec. 6-134. - License grant or denial, appeal rights. Each application on which the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County conducts a public hearing shall be granted or denied by it within a reasonable period of time from the date on which such public hearing is concluded. (1) In determining whether or not it is in the public interest and welfare for any license applied for hereunder to be granted or denied, in addition to all the other provisions of and qualifications required by this chapter, the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County shall be guided by the following: a. Reputation, character. The applicant's reputation, character, trade and business associations or past business ventures, mental and physical capacity to conduct this business. b. Previous violations of liquor laws. If the applicant is a previous holder of a license to sell alcoholic beverages whether or not he has violated any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business. c. Manner of conducting prior liquor business. If the applicant is a previous holder of a license to sell any type of alcohol, the manner in which he conducted the business thereunder, especially as to the necessity for unusual police observation and inspection in order to prevent the violation of any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business. d. Location. The location for which the license is sought, as to traffic congestion, available parking, general character of the neighborhood, pedestrian traffic, proximity to those establishments or entities listed in section 6-113 that are not within the prohibited distances set forth therein, and the feelings and attitudes of the citizens residing in the area as to the effect such an establishment would have on the adjacent and surrounding property values and on their quality of life. e. Number of licenses in the central business district. The number of licenses already granted for similar business in the central business district, as hereinbefore defined, and the need for an additional retail outlet of alcoholic beverages in the central business district. f. Dancing. Whether dancing will take place; whether live bands will be used; whether there will music on the inside or outside of the premises; if dancing, live bands or music is to be permitted upon the premises for which the license is sought and the applicant has previously permitted dancing upon any premises controlled or supervised by him, the manner in which he controlled and supervised such dancing to prevent any violation of any law, regulation or ordinance. g. Previous revocation of license.
