All employees should not arrive at work stations or record their time earlier than 15 minutes before starting time, or not to remain on the premises after closing time, unless permission has been granted for overtime. (i) Work away from premises or at home. A nonexempt employee shall not be permitted to perform work at home, unless approved in advance by the supervisor. If approved, work performed off the premises, job site or at home by a nonexempt employee may be counted as time worked. (j) Travel. Time spent in travel between the employees' home, and normal work location is not counted as time worked. However, when the employee travels to a special assignment in another county, the time spent traveling in excess of normal commuting time is counted as hours worked. (k) Time records for nonexempt employees. (1) The Federal Labor Standards Act plus state laws require that Georgetown-Quitman County, GA. keep records worked by nonexempt employees. These time records serve as evidence that Georgetown-Quitman County is conforming with the laws in its working hours and are a basis on which overtime is paid under the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act. (2) Time records must be complete and accurate. The maintenance of inaccurate records or the misrepresentation of the amount of time worked is a violation of the law. (l) Wage and salary changes. All recommendations for wage or salary increases of exempt or nonexempt employees shall be based on the employee's value to the Georgetown-Quitman County Government, as defined by the periodic evaluation of the job and the employee's demonstrated level of performance. (1) An absence of a day or more for illness or if the employee's attendance is unsatisfactory. (2) A deduction may be made to offset payment received for court or military duty. (3) The employee does not maintain an average of 40 hours per week during the work year. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-79. - Contributions, solicitations or distributions. Solicitations for contributions, sale of merchandise, circulation of petitions, solicitation of membership in clubs and organizations and all other forms of solicitations by employees are prohibited during office hours. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-80. - Courtesy. (a) Employees should operate in a manner both safe to themselves and their fellow workers; should report changes in his/her address or family status to their supervisor/county clerk, and should periodically check county bulletin boards for employee information. (b) Employees should not work in a manner that willfully obstructs or hinders other employees from completing their assigned duties; personal problems should not be pursued at work; telephones should not be used for personal telephone calls; and employees should not have personal visitors, unless permission is obtained. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-81. - Dress code. Although no formal dress code exists, you are asked to wear articles of clothing suitable to the type of work you do and the work environment in which you work. Articles of clothing should be neat, clean, in good taste, and not constitute a safety hazard. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-82. - Employment of relatives (nepotism). (a) An employee's relatives will not be employed by the Georgetown-Quitman County Commission under any of the following circumstances: (1) Where one of the parties would have authority (or practical power) to supervise, appoint, remove or discipline the other; (2) Where one party would be responsible for auditing the work of the other; (3) Where both parties would report to the same immediate supervisor (except in the case of temporary employees, in which case the employment may be allowed by the county manager); or (4) Where other circumstances might lead to potential conflict among the parties or conflict between the interest of one or both parties and the best interests of the county. (b) "Relatives" include an employee's parent, child, spouse, brother, sister-in-laws and step relationships. (c) If two employees marry, become related or begin sharing living quarters with one another, and in the county's judgment one or more of the potential problems noted above exist or reasonably could exist, only one of the employees will be permitted to stay with the county, unless reasonable accommodations, as determined by the county manager, can be made to eliminate the potential problem. The decision as to which relative will remain with the county must be made by the two employees within 30 calendar days of the date they marry, become related, or begin sharing living quarters with each other. If no decision has been made during this time, the county reserves the right to terminate either employee. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-83. - Drug-free workplace. (a) It is the policy the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County, that its workplace shall be drug-free in compliance with the Drug-Free Workplace Act of 1988 (PL100-690, Title V, Subtitle D). (b) The policy of Georgetown-Quitman County, GA., no employee shall engage in the unlawful manufacture, distribution, dispensing, possession or the use of a controlled substance in the workplace. (c) Each employee is instructed to hereby notify their supervisor and the county clerk of any criminal drug statute conviction for a violation in the workplace. Within 30 days, the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County, GA. must take action as appropriate. (d) Any employee violating the terms of this policy is subject to immediate dismissal. Employees found to be abusing drugs, but not convicted of any drug statute violation, will be subject to progressive discipline and required to satisfactorily participate in a rehabilitation program approved for such purpose at the employee's expense. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-84. - No smoking policy. For health and safety considerations, Georgetown-Quitman County prohibits smoking by employees in all Georgetown-Quitman County the facilities, including Georgetown-Quitman County-owned buildings, vehicles, and offices or other facilities rented or leased by Georgetown-Quitman County, including individual employee offices. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-85. - Equal employment opportunity. (a) Georgetown-Quitman County, GA. is an equal employment employer. Our long-stated policy has been clearly and simply stated as follows: (b) Georgetown-Quitman County, GA. reaffirms its policy treating all employees and applicants, whether or not they are members of minority groups, equally according to their individual qualifications, ability, experience, and other employment standards. There is to be no discrimination because of race, religion, color, national origin, sex, age, handicapped or veteran status. (c) It is equally the practice and policy of the Georgetown-Quitman County, GA. local government to comply with applicable federal, state and local labor laws. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-86. - Funeral flowers/retirement gifts. Georgetown-Quitman County funds shall not be expended for funeral or hospital flowers/gifts of employees/elected officials/or their families. Local voluntary employee contribution hospitality clubs are encouraged to pay for such items, including retirement parties. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-87. - Gambling. Georgetown-Quitman County takes a position that gambling among its employees can lead to bad morale, hard feelings and financial hardships. Therefore, gambling is prohibited on county premises and will be a cause for discipline. This includes card playing, dice, and other wagering. Any employee who is guilty of selling or attempting to sell football pools will be subject to discipline. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-88. - Garnishments. (a) A garnishment is a legal action by a creditor requiring Georgetown-Quitman County, GA. to withhold an amount from an employee's earnings. Georgetown-Quitman County must forward the amount to the creditor each payday until the debt has been paid. (b) When a garnishment is served on Georgetown-Quitman County, GA., the employee shall be contacted by the county clerk. The employee shall be asked to try to make an arrangement with the creditor to make direct payments to satisfy the indebtedness. If an agreement is reached, the employee will ask the creditor to issue a written release to Georgetown-Quitman County, GA. (c) If no release is received, or if, after receipt of a release the employee reneges on the agreement, Georgetown-Quitman County, GA. must process the garnishment. (d) Employees whose earnings are garnished or levied will be counseled on the wisdom of managing their personal affairs so as not to involve Georgetown-Quitman County. Garnishments against county employees leave a negative public view on all county employees in the community. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-89. - Grievances. (a) A grievance is a complaint you may have about your hours of work, your rights under personnel policies, your wages, seemingly unfair or unequal treatment or discipline, or other problems related to your employment. (b) Policy. It is policy of Georgetown-Quitman County to foster employee satisfaction and to give careful consideration and attention to any complaint. For the purposes of this rule, a grievance shall be considered to be any matter concerning an employee's status or conditions of employment for which appeal is not provided, or prohibited, in these rules and regulations. (c) Informal grievance procedure. An employee who has a problem or complaint should first try to get it settled through discussion with his immediate supervisor without delay. If, after this discussion, he does not believe the problem has been satisfactorily resolved, he shall have the right to discuss it with his supervisor's immediate superior, if any, in the administrative service. Every effort should be made to find an acceptable solution by informal means at the lowest possible level of supervision. If the employee is not in agreement with the decision reached by discussion, he shall then have the right to file a formal grievance in writing within five work days after receiving the informal decision or decisions. An informal grievance shall not be taken above the department head. (d) Formal grievance procedure. (1) First level of review. A grievance shall be presented in writing to the employee's immediate supervisor, who shall render his decision and comments in writing and return them to the employee within five work days after receiving the grievance. If the employee does not agree with his supervisor's decision, or the immediate supervisor fails to provide resolution of the grievance as outlined above, the employee may present the appeal in writing to his supervisor's immediate supervisor. Failure of the employee to do so with five work days after receipt of the written decision of his superior, or within ten work days if no decision is rendered will constitute a withdrawal of the grievance. (2) Further level or levels of review as appropriate. The supervisor receiving the grievance shall review it, render his decision and comment in writing, and return to the employee within five work days after receiving it. If the employee does not agree with the decision, or if no answer has been received within five work days after the supervisor receives the grievance, the employee may present the appeal in writing to the department head. Failure of the employee to take further action within five work days after receipt of the written decision of the supervisor, or within ten work days if no decision is rendered will constitute a withdrawal of the grievance. (3) Department review. The department head receiving the grievance, or his designated representative, shall discuss the grievance with the employee, his representative, if any, and with other appropriate persons. The department head shall render his decision and comments in writing, and return them to the employee within five days after receiving the appeal. If the employee does not agree with the decision reached, or if the department head fails to provide resolution of the grievance as outlined above, he may present his appeal in writing to the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County. Failure of the employee to take further action within five days after receipt of the written decision of the department head, or within ten work days if no decision is rendered shall constitute a withdrawal of the grievance. (4) County commission. The Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County, upon receiving the grievance, shall discuss the grievance with the employee, his representative, if any, and with other appropriate persons. The Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County shall render its decision and comments in writing, and return them to the employee within five work days after receiving the appeal. Decision of the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County is final. (e) Conduct of grievance procedures. (1) The time limits specified above may be extended to a definite date by mutual agreement of the employee and the reviewer concerned. (2) The employee may request the assistance of another person of his own choosing in preparing and presenting his appeal at any level of review. (3) The employee and his representative may be privileged to use a reasonable amount of work time as determined by the appropriate department head in conferring about and presenting the appeal. (4) The employee shall be assured freedom from reprisal for using the grievance procedures. (f) Employee counseling. At any time, an employee having a personnel problem may seek advice from his department head. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-90. - Appeal procedure. (a) Definition of appeal. For the purpose of these rules and regulations, appeal is the opportunity given an employee to request a hearing before the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County on a personnel action or matter which he believes adversely affects him when provision for such appeal is specifically provided in these rules and regulations (see rules on demotion, resignation, lay-off, suspension and dismissal). (b) Employee eligible for appeal. Only a permanent-status career employee is eligible to appeal a personnel action and request a hearing before the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County, GA. (c) Procedures for appeal. A permanent-status career employee, who has been adversely affected by a personnel action which may be appealed to the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County, GA., may appeal by filing a request in writing within five work days of notification of such adverse personnel action to the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County. It shall contain the employee's name, position, title, division, and department of office, and his home address. It shall also include the action complained of, a concise statement as to why the appeal is being filed, and such other information as may be required other provisions of these rules and regulations or which the employee believes to be directly related to the action being appealed. The Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County shall review the appeal and may consult with the employee's supervisor and department head if desired. They shall, within five work days after the receipt of the request for appeal, make a recombination. (d) Commission decision on formal hearing. The Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County shall review the employee's appeal in all cases in which these rules provide for appeal to the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County as soon as possible. If it is decided to grant the employee a hearing, the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County shall notify him of the hearing date, time and location; if it decides not to grant the employee a hearing, the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County shall notify him of its decision on his appeal from the adverse personnel action, giving its reasons therefore. The decision of the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County on whether or not to grant a hearing in the case shall be final. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-91. - Time and procedures for hearing. (a) Time limits. The Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County, GA. shall set the time, date and place for the hearing, which shall be no earlier that one week and not later than two weeks following commission's decision for allowing a hearing. (b) Hearing procedure. Unless otherwise specified by the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County and stated in its notice, the hearing shall be conducted as follows: (1) The department head, other administrative officials concerned, the county attorney, or other counsel representing the county service shall state the nature of the charge, that the action taken conforms with the provision of these rules, that such action is necessary and warranted and in the best interest of the county service; and he shall also present substantiating evidence. (2) When it appears to the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County, that the charges have not been substantiated to its satisfaction, the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County may take whatever equitable action it deems necessary at the time. (3) When the charges have been substantiated to the satisfaction of the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County, the appealing employee shall then be called upon to answer the charges and offer evidence in his behalf. (4) The Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County, at its discretion, may permit rebuttal and surrebuttal. (c) Conduct of hearing. The commission chairman or another member of the commission designated by the chairman to preside at the hearing has full authority at all times to maintain orderly procedure and restrict the hearing to relevant facts. All hearings shall be conducted in an orderly manner with a view of the presentation of all material and relevant facts so that a fair and impartial decision may be made. Commission members shall have the authority to seek diligently all information bearing on the case before, during and after any hearing. For the protection of the employee, hearings shall not be open to the public unless the employee specifically requests it. (d) Informality of hearing proceedings. A hearing before the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County need not be conducted in the same manner as in a court of law, and informality in the matter of taking testimony or in any other hearing proceedings shall not affect the validity of any findings or decisions made by the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County, GA. (e) Hearing continuance. Extension of time in scheduling a hearing or continuances in hearing may be granted or denied at the discretion of the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County, GA. Note—If the personnel action recommended is termination, a hearing must be granted. (f) Subpoena power. The Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County, GA. shall have the power to issue a subpoena and to require the attendance at a hearing of witnesses located within the county and the production by them of books, papers, and other materials pertinent to any matter of inquiry. A Georgetown-Quitman County Commission subpoena may be served by any person who could lawfully serve such subpoena in a civil case. A subpoena witness shall be paid the standard fee paid to a witness in county court. The Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County shall have the power to administer oaths and to examine all witnesses under oath in relation to any matter properly involved in a hearing. (g) Employee witness. Employees of the Georgetown-Quitman County Government may be required by the commission to attend and testify at a hearing without subpoena and without remuneration. Failure to comply with such requirement shall constitute grounds for dismissal. (h) Hearing of witnesses, depositions. Only witnesses having direct knowledge of the facts on which the charges are based will be heard by the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County, GA. Testimony of character witnesses will be received only in writing under oath, unless the commission agrees that the charges in the case involve moral or ethical issues in which cases, character witnesses and their cross-examination shall be allowed. At the discretion of the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County, statements of witnesses may be taken by written interrogatories or dispositions. (i) Investigations. The Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County may direct that necessary investigations be made, and at its discretion it may conduct its own investigations. (j) Record. At the discretion of the commission, a summary of verbatim record shall be made. The appealing employee may be supplied, at cost, a copy of the record. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-92. - Decision of county commission on appeals. (a) The county commission may decide an appeal it has heard in any manner that it deems necessary, appropriate, and in the best interest of the county service. The commission shall make its decision on an appeal as soon as possible after an appeal has been made and a hearing has been held. The same rules shall apply whenever the commission makes a decision on an employee's appeal without granting him a hearing. The county commission shall notify the appealing employee of its final decision on the appeal. (b) Testimonial procedures. (1) So that permanent-status career employees are afforded constitutional "due to process", department heads may not terminate an employee without pay. (2) When an employee has been suspended the supervisor or department head shall immediately notify the personnel office, in writing, of the circumstances to include employee's name, department, offense(s), time(s), date(s), and a statement that there is sufficient written documentation available to warrant the suspension, and a recommendation for termination. (3) From this information the personnel office will prepare a letter to the employee advising him that he has been suspended without pay pending a predetermination appeal hearing, the reason(s) for the suspension and recommended termination, that he has the right to a fair and impartial hearing, that he has the right to the counsel of his choice at his own expense if he so desires, and that he must request the appeal hearing in writing to the county commission, within five working days of his receipt of the letter or it will be assumed that he does not intend to request an appeal hearing and will be terminated effective with his date of suspension. (4) The letter of notification will be sent certified mail, return receipt requested. (5) If employee requests an appeal hearing, the appeal procedure Rule XII will be followed. (6) Employees who are still in their probation period may be terminated for cause, by department heads. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-93. - Discipline and terminations. (a) Discipline. (1) All employees are expected to exercise good judgment, loyalty, common sense, dedication, and courtesy in the performance of their duties. The primary mission of every employee is to provide courteous, orderly, efficient, and economic delivery of services to the citizens of the county. (2) Acts, errors or omissions which discredit the public service or impair the provision of orderly services to the citizens of the county may result in discipline, including termination. (3) The county manager or supervisor, as appropriate, has full discretion and authority to impose disciplinary action in accordance with the county policy and the circumstances of the particular case. (4) The following are examples of the types of behavior, which may result in discipline: a. Drinking alcohol or the abuse of nonprescription or prescription drugs or other controlled substances on the job, or arriving on the job under the influence of or while in possession of alcohol, drugs, or other controlled substances. b. Violation of a lawful duty. c. Insubordination. d. Absence from work without first notifying and securing permission from the supervisor. e. Habitual absence or tardiness for any reason. f. Unsatisfactory job performance, as determined by the county. g. Conviction of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. h. Acceptance of fees, gratuities or other valuable items in the performance of the employee's official duties for the county. i. Inability, refusal or failure to perform the duties of the assigned job. j. Violation of duties or rules imposed by this manual, or by any other county rule, regulation or administrative order. (5) This list is not all-inclusive, but only serves as a general guide. The county may discipline or terminate employees for other reasons not stated above. (6) In the event that discipline is necessary, the following types of disciplinary actions may be used, depending on the particular situation: a. Oral warning. An oral warning is a counseling session between the employee's supervisor and the employee on the subject of the employee's conduct and performance, or his/her failure to observe a rule, regulation, or administrative instruction. It is intended to increase an employee's efficiency and value to the county by changing the employee's conduct, attitude, habits, or work methods. Following the counseling session the supervisor shall document the oral warning. b. Reprimand. A reprimand is a formal written disciplinary action for misconduct, inadequate performance, or repeated lesser infractions. Written reprimands are placed in the employee's personnel file. c. Suspension. A suspension is a temporary, unpaid absence from duty, which may be imposed as a penalty for significant misconduct or repeated lesser infractions. A suspension is a severe disciplinary action which is made part of the employee's permanent record. (7) Suspensions with pay, where the employee is placed on administrative leave, may be utilized by the county manager pending the results of an investigation or disciplinary action where the county manager determines those factors such as public confidence, the safety of the employee or the efficient functioning of the county call for such a suspension. (b) Termination. (1) An employee may be terminated from county employment for any reasons listed below: a. During or at the end of the employee's trial period. b. As a result of disciplinary action. c. Due to loss of skills, certifications or other conditions which would make the employee unfit for service. d. When the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County has made a determination that a lack of work or funding exists with respect to the employee's position. The Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County has sole discretion to make determinations of lack of work or lack of funding. e. If the employee has a physical or mental impairment that prevents him/her from performing the required duties of the employee's position and the employee cannot be reasonably accommodated. Termination must be supported by medical evidence, which establishes that the individual is unable to perform bona fide job requirements. The county may require an examination at its expense performed by a physician of its choice. Failure to submit to such request may result in termination. (2) No employee will be disciplined or terminated for a discriminatory or otherwise illegal reason. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-94. - Separation of employment. Upon resignation or termination, any accrued unused annual leave will be included in the employee's final pay calculation. The final pay check will be paid on the next regular pay day for the county. An employee who resigns without giving two weeks notice will not receive payment for accrued unused annual leave. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-95. - Holidays. (a) Observed holidays. This section outlines the county's general practices related to eligibility and payment for holidays. The following holidays will be observed in all offices of the county:
(b) General policy. It shall be the policy of the county to ensure that all permanent full-time employees enjoy the same number of holidays each year. The standard shall be the number of holidays in a particular year which will be celebrated by permanent employees working a 40-hour week, Monday through Friday. For permanent employees on a workweek other than Monday through Friday, the Commission of Georgetown-Quitman County shall designate the workday that shall be observed. Permanent employees working less than full-time shall also be eligible to the above holidays with pay for their regular number of hours at their regular rate of pay. (c) Holidays falling on weekends. Holidays falling on weekends will normally be observed as designated by the county manager. Employees whose duties require them to work on a holiday shall receive compensation for the holiday. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-96. - Jury and witness duty. The county considers jury and witness duty an important community citizenship responsibility. Any employee shall be given necessary time off without loss of pay when performing jury duty or when required by proper authority to be a witness in legal proceedings. Employee will receive full pay for the necessary time off duty. County employees who perform jury duty or who are required to be a witness in a legal proceeding will be permitted to retain all fees and allowances received, therefore. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-97. - Lay-off. Lay-off is termination of employment of a career employee when, for any valid reason, it may be necessary to abolish one or more positions or reduce the number of employees in the county service. Lay-off does not reflect discredit on the service of the employee. The county commission shall be the final authority on lay-off decisions. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-98. - Leave of absence (without pay). (a) When it is deemed in the best interest of the county service, a permanent status career employee or a department head may be granted leave of absence for personal or other reasons, provided the department head recommend such leave and approved by the county commission. The granted leave of absence period may not exceed one year. Valid reasons for leave of absence include, but are not confined to, prolonged illness or disability of the employee or members of the household; educational or training enrichment; pregnancy and childbirth; and military service. (b) A leave of absence request must be submitted in writing in advance showing the employee's reason for requesting such leave of absence, plus a statement of intent to return to county service upon expiration of the leave of absence. (c) Employees will be reinstated in their former positions when leave of absences are two months or less. The employee will waive reinstatement rights and privileges of the position after two months, although strong efforts will be made to return the employee to the former position or to a comparable position upon expiration of the period of leave of absence. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-99. - Maternity leave. (a) Maternity leave will be treated as any other short-term disability leave without regard to paid/unpaid leave, benefit accruals, and county group insurance benefits. (b) The employee shall determine commencement of maternity leave and is based solely on the employee's inability to work. It will be handled as a nonaccidental disability. An employee who takes maternity leave will be placed in a comparable position with the same salary as that at the time of taking leave. She will retain the original date of employment. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-100. - Medical statement. A statement from the employee's physician is required prior to reinstatement following medical leave of five working days or more. It may be required for three or more days, when you take sick leave immediately before or after a paid holiday, or at your supervisor's discretion. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-101. - Military leave. County employees who are in the Reserve of the Armed Forces or National Guard and who perform duly "ordered military duty" will be granted military leave with pay. This time will not be deducted from sick or annual leave, but may not exceed 15 days at one time or a total of 15 days in one calendar year. The employee will receive his/her regular county pay for the period. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-102. - Outside employment. No employee shall engage in any other employment, or private business, or in the conduct of a profession, during the hours for which he or she are employed to work for the county. The county commission may establish limitations and procedures they deem necessary for regulating outside employment activities of county employees. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-103. - Privacy. (a) The county, as a public agency, must necessarily have a more open records policy than that of a private agency. The county must release specific information on salaries to the press and public agencies or groups, but will do so in the office, not on the telephone, at a mutually convenient time scheduled between the county, and the information requested. Only the county clerk or county commission is authorized to issue such information due to the delicacy of privacy and "public need to know" type laws. (b) The county shall maintain employee and dependent insurance records (such as benefits and claims information) separately and restrict the use of such records for employment-related decisions, unless there is a relevant purpose. (c) Medical information shall only be released on a "need-to-know" basis and should be restricted to relevant and/or job-related decisions where the health, safety or ability to perform is in question. Where possible, this information shall be stored separately. (d) Conviction records shall be maintained separately and their use shall be restricted. Arrest records will not be sought or used, except as specifically required by law. (e) Specific personnel performance records/memos shall also be part of the classified materials list kept separately by the supervisor/county clerk. Such data will not be released without written permission of the employee. (f) All requests for information about a current, retired, or terminated employee must be referred to the county clerk, who may disclose to prospective employers dates of employment, final title or position and job location. With employee's permission, a five-year employment and salary history may be given. (g) Information will also be given to duly authorized requests from law enforcement agencies, including investigations, summonses, subpoenas and judicial orders. The county need not inform an employee that personal information has been disclosed to law enforcement agencies if it concerns an investigation into the employee's on-the-job conduct, especially when an employee's actions endanger other employees or county security and property. (h) The county has a firm policy of respecting the dignity and worth of each individual employee while asking that the employee give the county his or her loyalty and best efforts in return. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-104. - Political activity. County policy is that employees shall remain politically "neutral." Political involvement should be limited to exercise of one's rights as a citizen in voting and expressing opinions privately or providing private personal contributions where desired by the employee. Work time shall not be expended in political campaigning, etc. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-105. - Promotion from within. As a matter of sound personnel practice, the county follows a policy of feeling higher level positions by promoting from within where feasible. In the event that there are not qualified applicants available for a position within the county workforce, the county will recruit applicants from outside sources in accordance with the county's affirmative action plan. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-106. - Public statements. (a) All statements to the press must be processed through the chief elected officials (county commission, sheriff, probate judge, and tax commissioner) or county clerk. (b) All major correspondence of the county to press or agency heads shall be prepared over the signature of the chairperson of the county commission when such correspondence represents either program commitments or county policy. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-107. - Procurement policy. All procurement shall be made in accordance with the adopted budget and policies of the county commission. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-108. - Reprimands. Reprimand is an oral or written notice of policy violation, mistakes, or other factors which may adversely influence employee's ability to efficiently carry out his duties and responsibilities. Any superior may reprimand a subordinate at any time for cause. (1) Oral reprimand. Oral reprimands will be considered the normal means of correcting the action of a subordinate. Such reprimands will not affect employee's privileges or status or be recorded in his or her personnel records. (2) Written reprimand. Written reprimands will be reserved for repeated offenses or those of a serious nature. When reduced to writing, they are required to be shown to the subordinate, who will acknowledge receipt of it over his signature. The subordinate, if he feels the written reprimand to be unjust, will so state, in writing, giving his reasons. Original copy of the written reprimand, together with the employee's acknowledgment and reply thereto, if any, will be forwarded to the county commission for inclusion in the individual's files. (3) Appeals from reprimand. Appeals from reprimand may be made through the grievance procedure, provided such appeal is instituted within five work days of date of oral reprimand or receipt, or written reprimand. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-109. - Seniority rights/termination. The county maintains no formal tenure system regarding its employees. Any employee can be separated from service by the county commission, regardless of seniority, for documented "good cause." Job security is based upon performance and reliability. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-110. - Sick leave. (a) The county allows sick leave to ensure that it, employees and their family against loss of income due to incapacitating illness or disability. Sick leave may also be granted when the illness of a member of the employee's household required the employee's personal attention. Sick leave may also be used upon the death of an immediate family member. (b) Beginning with the first day of employment, full-time employees qualify for sick leave at a rate of 3.69 hours per pay period, 26 pay periods in a year for a maximum of 95.94 hours a year. Sick leave may be accumulated and carried over from one calendar year to the next, but a maximum of 95 hours may be carried over. It may not be taken until it is accrued. (c) A written verification of illness from a physician may be required: (1) After you take sick leave of three or more days. (2) After you take sick leave immediately before or after a paid holiday. (3) At your supervisor's discretion. (d) In order to receive sick leave pay you must notify your supervisor of your condition on the first day out of work. (e) Sick leave will not be advanced. Sick leave is considered a privilege not be abused, not a right of the employee to use at their discretion. (Ord. of 4-3-07; Amend. of 2-11-14) Sec. 34-111. - Bereavement pay and time. Bereavement pay used by Georgetown-Quitman County employees, three days with pay to attend business and funeral matters of immediate family. Immediate family includes: Spouse, mother, father, mother-in-law, father-in-law, brother, sister, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, children, grandparents, grandchildren, nieces, nephews, aunt, uncle, live in partners, and any persons that may live in the household that may or may not be related to the employee. A funeral excuse shall be required by management before bereavement pay can be used. (Ord. of 4-3-07; Amend. of 2-11-14) Sec. 34-112. - Smoking. (a) It has been determined that it is not in the best interest of individual employees or the county as an employer for employees to smoke. It will cost smokers an estimated 15 years of their life span, plus it costs companies/agencies employing smokers $4,611.00 more than hiring nonsmokers on the average in addition to increasing turmoil from nonsmokers who do not wish to be "passive smokers" for various valid reasons. (b) It is the policy of county that smoking shall not be allowed inside county buildings. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-113. - Suspension. Suspension is the temporary removal of an employee from county service due to cause for a specified or indefinite period. (1) Suspension for disciplinary reasons. An employee who does not continue to do his work at an acceptable level of competence as determined by his performance evaluations, who is insubordinate or uncooperative, who acts in a manner tending to lower discipline or morale within the county service, or who acts in a manner deemed not in the best interest of the county service or in its good repute may be suspended for a reasonable period of time, not to exceed 30 days, when alternative personnel actions (demotion, dismissal, fine, etc.) may not be warranted, appropriate or deemed in the best interest of the county service. (2) Suspension pending a court decision. An employee may be suspended for a indefinite period when the county commission determines such action is necessary and in the best interest of the county service, in cases where an employee is charged with and awaiting trial for a criminal offense involving matters of prima facie prejudicial to the competent discharge of his duties and responsibilities. In these cases, the county commission may take such other action which they may deem necessary under the circumstances. After the employee has been tried and a verdict reached by the court or an entry of nolle prosequi has been made, the county commission shall make a final determination as to whether the employee shall be reinstated, dismissed or subject to whatever disciplinary action that may be considered to be necessary and appropriate in consideration of the facts of the case. (3) Suspension during investigation of charges. When an employee has acted or is alleged to have acted in a manner which would subject him to dismissal from the county service, he may be suspended by the county commission for a period not in excess of one month while the county commission is investigating charges before making a final determination as to whether the employee would be dismissed from the county service. An employee who is exonerated of charges following investigation shall be reinstated without loss of pay, privileges, benefits, or status, retroactive to date of suspension. (4) Suspension recommendations. When the department head deems such action is necessary, appropriate and in the best interest of the county service, a department head may recommend that an employee be suspended. The recommendation shall be in writing and shall contain the reasons why it is necessary for the department head to recommend suspension and the type and duration of the suspension. When alternative disciplinary personnel actions might be appropriate, the department head shall state why he selected suspension. The county commission may also initiate suspension. (5) Delegation of suspension authority. The county commission may, at its discretion, delegate suspension authority to department heads, office heads, and selected division chiefs whenever it deems such delegation of authority is necessary to maintain the good order and good repute of the county services. Delegation of suspension authority shall be made in writing by the county commission. (6) Notice of suspension. Upon notification of approval of a suspension recommendation, the county commission shall notify the employee in writing of the suspension and reasons therefore. A permanent status career employee shall be informed when he has the right to appeal a suspension. Probation status employees do not have the right of appeal. (7) Suspension which may be appealed. Any suspension for disciplinary reasons or a suspension during an investigation of charges may be appealed pursuant to rule XII. A suspension pending a court decision may also be appealed, in which case consideration will be given only to whether the county commission's action was consistent with requirements of paragraph 8.04 of this rule and in the best interest of the county service. Appeals must be made within five work days of receipt of written notification of suspension, or suspension shall become final without further action. (Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 34-114. - Return to work program. (a) It is the policy of Georgetown-Quitman County to provide and establish a return to work policy for employees with work-related injuries and illnesses who are unable, temporarily and/or permanently, to return to their permanent job duties. (b) Because Georgetown-Quitman County recognizes that their employees are a valued and limited resource, this program is designed to: • Assist the recovery process by providing a focus and a goal for return of the injured employee. • Benefit employees by allowing them to return to full wages as soon as possible. • Benefit employer by reducing workers' compensation costs. (c) Process. (1) Georgetown-Quitman County will seek return to work opportunities as quickly as medically possible through the use of transitional employment for all employees who are temporarily disabled due to an on the-job-injury. All transitional employment duties must be productive. Duties must never be demeaning or appear worthless in any way. (2) Georgetown-Quitman County, through their reasonable accommodation program, will make efforts to retain employees who are permanently disabled. (Ord. of 5-10-11) Secs. 34-115—34-140. - Reserved.

div.head: Chapter 36 - PARKS AND RECREATION
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 36-1—36-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - RIVER BLUFF WALKING TRAIL
Sec. 36-31. - Rules of conduct. (a) Rules of conduct for River Bluff Walking Trail. (1) The trail is open from sunrise to sunset. (2) No littering. (3) No food or glass containers on trail. (4) No motorized vehicles except for ambulatory disabled. (5) Children under 12 shall be accompanied and supervised by an adult. (6) No horses. (7) Dogs must be on leash. (8) No weapons or intoxicants. (9) No fires. (10) No cutting, carving, uprooting, or damaging of plants or trees. (11) No hunting. (12) Users must maintain discipline and order. (13) Roller skates, roller blades, skateboards, bicycles, and tricycles are prohibited. (b) Persons failing to comply with the walking trail and the general park regulations set forth by Georgetown-Quitman County Commission may be denied future use of these facilities. (c) Any damage to the walking trail/park facility should be reported to the office of the board of commissioners (229) 334-0903 as soon as possible. If you witness a crime or damage call 911 immediately. (Ord. No. 01-13, 3-12-13) Secs. 36-32—36-50. - Reserved.

div.head: Chapter 38 - ROADS AND BRIDGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Any ordinance naming, renaming, opening, closing, prescribing grades, etc., of streets, roads, bridges and other public ways saved from repeal, § 1-10(11); buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; community development, ch. 18; littering, spitting on sidewalks, public buildings, § 42-40; utilities, ch. 50; subdivisions, app. A; general requirements for streets and other rights-of-way, app. A, art. XII; street design requirements, app. A, art. XIII. State Constitution reference— Powers of county as to streets, roads and stormwater systems, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III. State Law reference— State, county and municipal road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-1 et seq.; naming state roads, bridges or interchanges, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-3; removal and relocation of utility facilities necessitated by construction of public roads, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-170 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 38-1—38-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - NAMING OF PUBLIC AND PRIVATE ROADS
Sec. 38-31. - Findings; purpose. In accordance with the power and authority vested in the board of commissioners, the board of commissioners has determined that it is in the best interest of the health, welfare and safety of the citizens of the county, that this article be enacted to govern, regulate and control the naming of county roads; so that there will not be two roads in the county known by the same name and to adopt procedures for the assignment of names of all county roads. (Ord. of 4-14-1998) Sec. 38-32. - Naming of county roads. (a) The board of commissioners will adopt an official county road list, and the names of all roads on that road list shall be the official name of each road in the county. (b) The board of commissioners shall approve an official county map identifying all roads in the county, and the roads shall be known by the names identified on that official county map. (c) All present and future roads, public and private, in the county will be named by the board of commissioners. Recommended names of roads may be submitted to the board of commissioners. The name must be approved by the board of commissioners before being officially added to the official road list. Approval may be accomplished following procedures set forth by the board. (d) Before any road is accepted by the board of commissioners as a county road, the individual desiring to dedicate the road to the county must, in addition to the other requirements of dedicating roads to the county, notify the board of commissioners or its designee of the proposed name of each road to be dedicated. (1) The county clerk shall cause the official road list of the county to be searched to determine if there is a county road on the official county road list with the same name as the name requested for the new road. (2) The county clerk shall notify the individual wishing to dedicate the road that the name suggested is, or is not, the name of a road that is currently used. If the name is one that is already used, another name will be required to be submitted for the road. (3) If the name of the new road is not being used, the county clerk shall inform the board of the new name, and, that it is not a duplicate road name. New roads that are extensions of existing roads may be given the name of the existing road. (e) The board of commissioners may accept the road with the name offered, or, at the board's discretion, may refuse the name offered and change the name of the road to a name that is acceptable to the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 4-14-1998, §§ 1—5) Sec. 38-33. - Road list and county map. The road list and county map, as now or hereafter amended, are incorporated in this section as if set out at length in this section.

div.head: Chapter 42 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; utilities, ch. 50. State Constitution reference— Power of county to provide garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III. State Law reference— Waste management, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-1 et seq.; litter control, O.C.G.A. §§ 16-7-40 et seq., 36-1-20; transporting refuse across county boundary for dumping without permission, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-16.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 42-1. - Solid waste management plan. The county's solid waste management plan, as now or hereafter amended, is incorporated in this section as if set out at length in this section. Secs. 42-2—42-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - WASTE MANAGEMENT; LITTER CONTROL
Sec. 42-31. - Title; purpose. This article shall be known as the Quitman County Solid Waste Ordinance. It is the purpose of this article to provide for the healthy and sanitary management and disposal of solid waste in the county to ensure the public health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the county and encourage recycling of selected material through education and voluntary compliance. It shall apply to the preparation, storage, collection and disposal of all solid waste and shall prohibit unsanitary conditions in the unincorporated areas of the county, as presently or hereafter established. (Ord. of 10-12-1998) Sec. 42-32. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Ashes means the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke or other combustible materials. Bag means a flexible container with a hole at one end, capable of being closed by tying or twisting and made of plastic or other material designed and made to hold not over the number of pounds of household garbage set by the board of commissioners. Brown goods means furniture, mattresses and similar residential or office furnishings. Building material means any material defined as, but not limited to, lumber, brick, block, stone, carpet, plumbing materials, plaster, concrete, roofing, floor tile, gutters or other substances accumulated as a result of the construction of or repairs or additions to structures or accessory structures or the demolition of such. Business trash means any accumulation of paper, cardboard, packaging materials, rags or accumulations other than garbage or household trash, which result from the operation of stores, offices and similar business or commercial enterprises. Commercial establishment means any hotel, motel, restaurant, business, public or semipublic establishment of any kind, and any master-billed apartment, excluding industrial establishments. An operation conducted from a residence requiring a business license is a commercial establishment for purposes of this article. A mobile home park is a commercial establishment. Commercial solid waste means all types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses and other nonmanufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial waste. Container means a refuse receptacle and/or bags or sacks furnished by the county. Disposal site means an area, location, tract of land or facility used or intended to be used for the disposal of solid waste, putrescible waste or other waste. Garbage means the byproduct resulting from the growing, harvesting, processing, handling, preparation, cooking or consumption of animal or vegetable food, or other matter which is subject to decomposition, decay, putrefaction or the generation of noxious or offensive gases or odors, or which during or after decay may serve as breeding areas or feeding material for flies, insects or animals. Hazardous refuse means solid wastes and other materials which: (1) Have been defined as hazardous wastes pursuant to the Solid Waste Disposal Act (42 USC 6901 et seq.) or regulations promulgated by the state board of natural resources at chapter 391-3-11. (2) Have been defined as hazardous substances pursuant to the Comprehensive Environmental Response Compensation and Liability Act (42 USC 9601 et seq.); or (3) Constitute a hazard to health or safety, such as poison, acids, caustic matter or solutions, chemicals, infected materials, offal, fecal matter, explosives, radioactive materials and highly flammable substances. Household trash means residential waste accumulation usually attendant upon housekeeping, such as paper, sweepings, dust, rags, bottles, cans or other residential refuse of any kind, other than garbage, excluding hazardous refuse, ashes and building material. Industrial establishment means any establishment involved in the manufacture or assembly of a product or any part thereof. Industrial waste means all waste, including solids, semisolids, sludge and liquids, created by or resulting from the operation of factories, processing plants or other manufacturing enterprises. Laws means applicable federal, state and local laws, statutes, rules, regulations, ordinances and other governmental requirements. Litter means all discarded manmade materials, including, but not limited to, garbage, household trash, industrial waste, building materials, appliances or portions thereof, refuse, waste materials, sand, gravel, slag, brickbats, rubbish, tin cans, trash, debris, dead animals or any other discarded, used or unconsumed substance which is not handled in accordance with the provisions of this article. Loading and unloading area means a space or area used by any moving vehicle for the purpose of receiving, shipping and transporting goods, wares, commodities and persons. Master-billed apartments, etc., means those residential apartment complexes where the solid waste billing is paid by the owner of the complex. Mobile home park means a parcel of land which has been planned and improved for the placement of two or more mobile homes, or two or more recreational vehicles, for nontransient use and for rent. Multiple family dwelling (multifamily) means a building designed for or occupied by two or more families, such as apartments, duplexes and triplexes. Municipal solid waste means garbage and household trash, except hazardous refuse. Person means any natural person, whether the owner, agent or tenant; any corporation, partnership, association, firm, receiver, guardian, trustee, executor, administrator, fiduciary, occupant, lessee, tenant or representative of any of the same. Public property and private property mean the right-of-way of any road or highway; any body of water or watercourse or the shores or beaches thereof; any park, playground, building, refuge or conservation or recreation area; and residential or farm properties, timberlands or forests. Refuse means solid waste accumulations consisting of any combination of ashes, building material, garbage, hazardous refuse, household trash and other waste or discarded materials of all kinds. Refuse receptacle means a container or bag approved by the county as acceptable for the temporary reception and storage of refuse pending transportation to a permanent disposal site. The term shall include plastic bags where approved by the county. Rules and regulations means the detailed rules and regulations approved by the board of commissioners the board or its designee is authorized to use and enforce for the efficient and safe operation of this article. Sanitation fee means the amount to be paid by the persons and entities responsible under the terms of this article for the sanitary handling or disposal of solid waste by the county or their designee. Scavenge and scavenging mean the unauthorized and uncontrolled retrieval of discarded refuse materials. White goods means appliances such as stoves and refrigerators. Yard trimmings means leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance other than mining, agricultural and silvicultural operations. (Ord. of 8-8-1995, § 1; Ord. of 10-12-1998, §§ I, II) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. State Law reference— Definitions pertaining to solid waste management generally, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-22; definitions pertaining to hazardous waste management, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-62; "litter" defined, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-42. Sec. 42-33. - Administration. (a) Authority of clerk of board of commissioners. The county commissioners, or their designee, shall have charge of the administration of this article. (b) Residential and commercial service. (1) All residential, including, but not limited to, single-family residences, multifamily dwellings and mobile home parks, and commercial establishments in the unincorporated portions of the county are required to utilize the solid waste collection service of the county for the disposition of all garbage and household trash, except hazardous refuse, generated by such residences and commercial establishments, which shall be collected once a week. All other refuse, except hazardous refuse, shall be taken, by the residents or commercial establishments producing the other refuse, to the county transfer station located at Keigler Road in the county and operated by the county, all in conformity with laws. (2) Notwithstanding anything in this article to the contrary and consistent with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 12-8-30.10, any individual may dispose of solid waste originating from his own residence onto land or facilities owned by him when disposal of such waste does not thereby adversely affect the public health and is in accordance with applicable laws. However, the sanitation fee provided for in this article must be paid. (c) Receptacles and containers required. Every person in possession, charge or control of any residence or commercial establishment unit upon which municipal solid waste is accumulated or produced shall be initially provided a container or bags by the county for the deposit of municipal solid waste generated at such residence or commercial establishment unit. If one container or bag is not sufficient, an additional container may be obtained at the cost of the user, but additional bags may be obtained without cost upon request. The monthly fee will be as per the rate schedule adjusted from time to time by the board of commissioners. The container or bag shall be kept in a suitable place readily accessible to the solid waste collection crews of the county, or its designees, as the case may be, for the storage of all such municipal solid waste which will normally accumulate between the established collection dates. The county shall determine the type, size, specifications, number and location of the receptacles and shall determine whether the receptacles and containers are in a serviceable condition. (d) Receptacles and containers to be safe. All receptacles and containers shall be maintained in a good serviceable condition at all times. All bags shall be closed and secured so the contents shall not spill out of the bag. Any receptacle or container which does not conform to the requirements of this article or to the rules and regulations of the clerk, or which has ragged or sharp edges or other defects likely to hamper or injure the person collecting the contents therefrom or the public generally, shall be replaced by the county at the expense of the owner. (e) Fees. Each residential unit shall pay an amount per month set by the board of commissioners, or the amount designated in the future. Each commercial establishment unit shall pay in accordance with the schedule of charges stated in section 42-39. (f) Addresses. To make the implementation of this article as efficient and cost effective as possible, the owner of any residence, rental property, business or commercial establishment shall furnish the county with correct addresses for billing and for correct identification of the owner of the property. (Ord. of 10-12-1998, § II) Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. Sec. 42-34. - Precollection practices. The following practices and procedures shall be followed by persons in the unincorporated areas of the county in order to facilitate the collection of solid waste: (1) Refuse. All refuse shall be managed by such persons in accordance with applicable laws and all municipal solid waste shall be placed and maintained in containers satisfying the requirements of this article and of the rules and regulations of the county. Containers shall be maintained at all times with tightfitting lids or covers, and secured in such manner as to prevent the overturning by the elements or by dogs or other animals. (2) Garbage. Garbage placed in containers for collection shall be enclosed in paper or plastic bags. Garbage shall be drained of all liquids prior to its being placed in refuse receptacles or bags. (3) Injurious trash items. Municipal solid waste or refuse brought to the county transfer station with a potential for inflicting injury, such as broken glass, lightbulbs, sharp pieces of metal, fluorescent tubes and television tubes shall be securely packaged or wrapped in such a manner as will prevent injury to the collection crews or other persons and to prevent the puncture of the bags. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to material placed in mechanically handled containers. (4) Hazardous refuse. Hazardous refuse will not be collected by the county. No person shall place any hazardous refuse in any refuse receptacle or other container for collection by the county and shall not haul or deliver any hazardous refuse to the county transfer station. All applicable laws relating to the generation, management, handling, treatment, storage or disposal of hazardous refuse shall be observed by all persons, and the county reserves the right to report any discovered or known violations of such laws to the appropriate state, federal or local authorities. (5) Building materials. Building materials will not be collected by the county. The owner of the premises or the contractor, builder or person doing the repairs, remodeling, construction or demolition shall be required to haul and transfer the debris to the county transfer station. (6) Tree and vegetable removal by home occupants. Trees cut by the owner or occupant shall be taken to the county transfer station by the owner. When a tree is cut from private property by anyone other than the owner, such person shall remove and legally dispose of all wood and limbs. The owner, tenant or other persons in possession of the property shall be responsible to see that such tree trimmer or other person outlined above complies with this provision. (7) Other. Grass clippings, leaves, pine straw and/or pine cones shall be disposed of as provided in subsection (6) of this section. (8) Ashes. It shall be unlawful to deposit hot ashes in garbage containers or bags. Cooled ashes may be deposited in bags. Loose ashes or clinkers shall not be placed or deposited upon streets, sidewalks or side parks. (9) Pet litter. Pet litter must be placed in securely tied bags, not to exceed ten pounds in weight, and placed in the container, when containers are used by the county. (10) Household furniture and furnishings. Household furniture, furnishings and brown goods shall be disposed of as provided in subsection (6) of this section. (11) Appliances. Appliances (white goods) shall be disposed of as provided in subsection (6) of this section. (12) Disposable diapers. Disposable diapers must be placed and tied securely in bags and placed in the regular container or bags. (Ord. of 10-12-1998, § III) Sec. 42-35. - Collection practices. (a) Residential. Garbage accumulated by residents shall be stored in refuse receptacles complying with the requirements of the county as to size, shape and materials, and shall be placed at such locations convenient for servicing by the county as shall be designated by the board of commissioners for weekly pickup. Service for disabled citizens will be handled as by the rules and regulations implemented by the board of commissioners once the disability is certified by a licensed physician and the certification is submitted to the clerk for approval. (b) Commercial. Refuse accumulated by commercial establishments shall be stored in containers meeting the requirements of the county as to size, shape and materials, and such receptacles shall be compatible with the collection equipment and methods of the county. (c) Issuance of permits. The board of commissioners or its designee shall not issue a building permit for industrial establishments, commercial establishments or multifamily dwellings until the county gives its approval to proposed plans for the storage, disposal and other management of refuse, and until the applicant for a permit has submitted proof that all of the applicant's taxes and fees due the county are paid and are current. The term "applicant's taxes and fees" includes any and all taxes and fees on property that the applicant has an interest in or is responsible for managing. (d) Locations of containers. The county will not collect municipal solid waste from commercial establishments or multifamily dwellings unless the municipal solid waste is placed in approved containers and located at a place approved by the county. (e) Multifamily units. All multifamily dwellings of 50 or more units served by the county shall be containerized with plastic or metal containers furnished by the county. Multifamily dwellings of less than 50 units serviced by the county may be containerized with plastic or metal containers furnished by the county as determined by the county in accordance with section 42-33(c). (f) Containerizing trash. All commercial establishments shall containerize all refuse generated by the establishment including outside as well as inside debris from the premises. (g) County transfer station. All industrial waste, building material, roofing material, material from remodeling and demolition that is hauled and taken to the county transfer station in accordance with this article, shall be hauled and taken by the owner or by the person responsible to the owner for the removal of such material in compliance with applicable laws. (Ord. of 10-12-1998, § IV) Sec. 42-36. - Wheeled garbage containers. (a) Inspections. Where a wheeled garbage container is furnished by the county, it shall be normally the only container authorized for garbage collection and shall be subject to inspection by the county. Should additional containers be needed, they may be obtained for a fee by contacting the clerk. (b) Placing for collection. The owner, occupant, tenant or other person occupying any building, house or structure within the unincorporated areas of the county as a residence or business using a wheeled garbage container or bag shall have such container at the curb or designated location not earlier than 7:00 p.m. on the day before and not later than 7:00 a.m. on the designated garbage pickup days. (c) Removal after collection. The owner, occupant, tenant or other person occupying any building, house or structure within the unincorporated areas of the county as a residence or business using a wheeled garbage container for curbside service shall return such container to the side or rear of the building no later than 24 hours after collection. Where the collection point is located more than 100 yards from a home, the container may be stored at another location approved by the clerk. (d) Vacating dwelling. Wheeled garbage containers furnished by the county shall not be removed from the premises to which they are delivered. The county will be notified if a residence or building is vacated, and the owner, or person in charge, shall fill out and sign the proper documents furnished by the county. (e) Loss or damage to container. If the wheeled container furnished by the county is damaged, lost or destroyed through negligence of the person to whom the container was assigned, the person shall reimburse the county for the cost of a replacement container. (Ord. of 10-12-1998, § V) Sec. 42-37. - Commercial establishments. (a) Generally. Commercial establishments shall store refuse in containers meeting the requirements of applicable laws, including, but not limited to, this article and the rules and regulations promulgated by the county in part to eliminate wind driven debris and unsightly litter in and about the establishment. Any spillage or overflow shall be cleaned up immediately by such establishment. (b) Loading and unloading areas. All loading and unloading areas shall be provided with appropriate refuse receptacles for loose debris, paper, packaging materials and other trash and refuse. The owner or occupant of the commercial establishment shall place a sufficient number of containers, not less than the number required by the rules and regulations adopted by the board of commissioners for that establishment, in such area to maintain a clean, neat and sanitary condition at all times. The occupant of the premises shall maintain surveillance to ensure that all refuse is placed in the proper container in compliance with applicable laws, including, but not limited to, this article, and that the area is kept clean and free of litter. (Ord. of 10-12-1998, § VI) Sec. 42-38. - Prohibited activities. The following activities are declared to be unlawful and in violation of this article: (1) Public streets and private property. No person shall place any litter, refuse, garbage or trash in any street, median strip, alley or other public place of travel, nor upon any other public property, nor upon any private property except with the written consent of the owner or occupant thereof, and then only in accordance with the provisions of this article. (2) Blockage of drainage. No person shall place any litter, refuse, trash, trees, grass, refuse receptacles, containers or garbage on, over or so close to any drainage culvert, manhole or ditch as to cause such material to interfere in any way with the proper and efficient drainage. (3) Appliances. No person shall leave outside any building in a place accessible to children any appliance, refrigerator or other container which has an airtight snap lock or similar device without first removing therefrom the door. This subsection shall not apply to any appliance, refrigerator or container which has been placed on or adjacent to the rear of the building and which has been crated, strapped or locked so that it will be impossible for a child to obtain access to any compartment thereof. (4) Vacant units, lots and rental units. No owner or occupant of any property in the unincorporated areas of the county shall allow litter, garbage, refuse, rubbish, filth, debris, building material, household trash or yard trimmings to accumulate on their property. The county will not remove such accumulation from the property. If any owner, occupant or other person responsible for the existence of any of such conditions shall fail to remedy the conditions within seven days, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, after notice, such conditions shall be a violation of this article and abatable as a nuisance. (5) Scavenging. No person other than the owner thereof shall disturb or interfere with any container used for the purpose of storing refuse pending its collection, or remove any contents therefrom, or remove such container from its location. (6) Scattering of refuse and littering prohibited. No person shall: a. Throw or deposit any refuse on any public or private street or scatter such refuse or litter on any public or private property. b. Throw or deposit any refuse, trash or debris in any marsh area, stream, drainage ditch, body of water or beach area. (7) Use of streets and roads. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle transporting loose material on any of the roads of the county to transport the loose material without suitable covers securely fastened to the vehicle in such a manner as to prevent the loose material from being deposited on the streets or adjoining areas. (8) Unlawful dumping. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, drop, dump or otherwise leave any litter on the premises of another without the consent of such other person, and without complying with applicable laws, including, but not limited to, this article and the rules and regulations of the county adopted pursuant to this article. (9) Ownership of refuse. All refuse, including refuse deposited in refuse containers provided by the county, shall be and shall remain the property of the owner or occupant until the refuse has been placed in vehicles of the county or its designee in accordance with this article. The county has no responsibility or liability for any injuries or damage resulting from such refuse. (Ord. of 10-12-1998, § VII) Sec. 42-39. - Fees. Each commercial establishment unit shall pay the following fees based on per cubic yard of refuse:
(Ord. of 10-12-1998, Exhibit "A") Sec. 42-40. - Littering, spitting on sidewalks, public buildings. It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or spit hulls, peelings or other litter upon the sidewalk or in or upon the floors of public buildings, and other similar places and property. (Ord. of 8-8-1995, § 6) Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; roads and bridges, ch. 38. Sec. 42-41. - Distribution of advertising literature. (a) It shall be unlawful to place in or upon any automobile in the county any handbill, bumper sticker, circular, pamphlet, poster, postcard or other literature except with the permission, express or implied, of the owner or occupant of such automobile. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to place on public property any handbill, circular, pamphlet, poster, postcard or other literature, except with the express permission of the board of commissioners. (c) Any person desiring to place any handbills, circulars, pamphlets, posters, postcards or other literature on public property within the county shall first post up to a $100.00 cash bond with the clerk of the county when required by the county, along with obtaining permission from the board of commissioners to distribute such materials. The bond shall be returned upon request, provided such literature and materials are removed within a reasonable time after the event which they promote. This section is not intended to regulate nor prohibit the right of a merchant to place or allow the placement of such literature within his commercial establishment or on his storefront. (Ord. of 8-8-1995, § 8) Sec. 42-42. - Abandoned vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon any motor vehicle on public rights-of-way or public property without express permission from the board of commissioners or on private property without permission from the owner of such property. A vehicle shall be considered abandoned if it remains in one place for a period exceeding 72 hours. (Ord. of 8-8-1995, § 17) Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 46. Sec. 42-43. - Nonoperating vehicles. All persons living within the county, owning a nonoperating motor vehicle, shall keep such vehicle reasonably obscured from public view. (Ord. of 8-8-1995, § 18) Sec. 42-44. - Enforcement. (a) Generally. It is the principal objective of this article to attain a clean, healthy, safe and litter-free community. Enforcement procedures shall be utilized only where other means fail. (b) Solid waste management plans. A solid waste management plan must be submitted with every application for a building permit. The inspection department shall obtain the approval of the county of the solid waste management plan. The management plan submitted shall be consistent with the county's management plan as approved by the state. (c) Monitoring by employees. Solid waste collection employees, inspection department employees, and other county employees shall be alert to observe violations of the provisions of this article, including, but without limitation, loose trash and garbage, waste, litter, containers not in compliance, or any other thing or matter which may be in violation of this article or the rules and regulations of the county. An employee observing such violations shall report the same to his supervisor, who in turn shall cause the information to be conveyed to the county for required action. (d) Collection of sanitation fees. The fees due the county or its designee shall be paid promptly every month, in advance, and if not paid in a timely manner, shall be collected by the county through any lawful means. On any bills 30 days late, there will be a late fee of $5.00 charged to such bills. Also, the nonpayment of the fees provided for in this article shall constitute a lien against the real and personal property of the person or legal entity responsible for the payment of the fees. Should any person liable for the payment of the fees fail to pay the fees within 15 days of having been billed, the clerk is authorized to issue an execution against such person and deliver the execution to the sheriff for levy and sale as provided by law. (e) Penalty for violation.
