A space not less than nine (9) by eighteen (18) feet plus maneuvering space within a parking lot or on a single-family dwelling lot expressly provided for [the] purpose of parking an automobile or other vehicle. 2.37 [3.37] Patio House. A single-family dwelling in which most or all of a lot is used with yard space combined instead of divided. Front, rear, and side yards are consolidated into one garden area, either partially or completely bordered by rooms or enclosed by walls. 3.38 Planned Unit Development (PUD). A group of three (3) or more buildings constructed on a plot of un-subdivided ground at least two (2) acres in size, which provides for common open spaces and a variety of choice in housing types and land utilization. Land ownership or rental patterns may vary, with rental units, cooperatives, and condominiums being choices open to PUD developers. If common open spaces, including streets, are not dedicated for public use, legal agreements shall be provided for approval by the County Commission and shall include [a] provision for adequate future maintenance. The terms "planned unit development" and "PUD" are interchangeable. 3.39 Recreational Vehicle. A vehicular, portable structure built on a chassis, designed to be either pulled by another vehicle or self-propelled, to be used as a temporary dwelling for travel and recreational purposes. The term "recreational vehicle" includes the terms "RV," "motor home," "travel trailer," and related wheeled recreational equipment not designed for year-round occupancy. 3.40 Roadside Stand. A small-scale business structure permanently or seasonally located within an agricultural or rural area for the sale of agricultural products primarily produced on the premises and using only signs that are removed during seasons when the business is closed. 3.41 Sign. The term "sign" shall mean and include every outdoor advertising device, billboard, poster, panel, freestanding ground sign, roof sign, projecting sign, pylon sign, illuminated sign, sign painted on a wall, window, marquee, awning or canopy, and shall include any announcement, declaration, demonstration, display, ribbon, banner, illustration, or insignia used to advertise or promote the interests of any person when the same is placed in view of the general public traveling along a public street or road right-of-way. 3.42 Signs, Number and Surface Area. For the purpose of determining number of signs, a sign shall be considered to be a single display surface or display device containing elements organized, related, and composed to form a unit. Where matter is displayed in a random manner without organized relationship of elements, or where there is reasonable doubt about the relationship of elements, each element shall be considered to be a single sign. The surface area of a sign shall be computed as including the entire area within a regular geometric form or combinations of regular geometric forms comprising all of the display area of the sign and including all of the elements of the matter displayed. Frames and structural members not bearing advertising matter shall not be included in computation of surface area. 3.43 Sign, On-Site. An outdoor advertising device relating in its subject matter to the premises on which it is located, or to products, accommodations, services, or activities on the premises. The terms "point-of-sale" sign and "on-premises" signs are synonymous with "on-site" sign. 3.44 Sign, Off-Site. An outdoor advertising device other than an on-site including those erected by the outdoor advertising industry. 3.45 Street. A dedicated and accepted public right-of-way for vehicular traffic which affords the principal means of access to abutting properties. 3.46 Structure. Anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires a fixed location on the ground or which is attached to something having a fixed location on the ground. 3.47 Tourist Home. A dwelling in which sleeping accommodations in less than ten (10) rooms are provided or offered for the use of guests in return for compensation. Any dwelling in which such accommodations are offered in ten (10) or more rooms shall be deemed to be a hotel as herein defined. The use of a dwelling as a tourist home shall not be considered as an accessory use nor a customary home occupation. 3.48 Tract. See "Lot," 3.27. 3.49 Use, Accessory. See "Accessory," 3.01. 3.50 Use, Conditional. See "Conditional Use," 3.08. 3.51 Use, Principal. The primary purpose for which a lot is occupied and/or used. 3.52 Variance. A modification of the strict terms of this resolution granted by the Board of Appeals where such modification will not be contrary to the public good, such as irregular lot size, topographic or other characteristics of the land, and not as the result of any action on the part of the property owner, a literal enforcement of this resolution would result in unnecessary and undue hardship. 3.53 Wetlands. Those lands classified as "poorly or very poorly drained soils" by the U.S. Department of Agriculture Soil Conservation Service in the Soil Survey of Quitman County, Georgia. 3.54 Yard. A required space on the same lot with a principal building, open, unoccupied, and unobstructed by buildings or structures from ground to sky except where encroachments of accessory buildings and other structures are expressly permitted. 3.55 Yard, Front. A yard situated between the front building line and the front lot line and extending the full width of the lot. 3.56 Yard, Rear. A yard situated between the rear building line and the rear lot line and extending the full width of the lot. 3.57 Yard, Side. A yard situated between a side building line and the front yard to the rear yard. ARTICLE IV. - PLATTING JURISDICTION AND ENFORCEMENT
Section 401. - Platting Authority. From and after May 9, 1995, the Quitman County Commission shall be the platting authority. Section 402. - Preliminary Plat Approval Required Prior to Initiation of Construction. No construction work shall be undertaken on a proposed land subdivision until a preliminary plat has been approved by the Board of Commissioners and the requirements of Section 706 have been satisfied. Section 403. - Land Subdivision Plat Recording. No plat of a land subdivision shall be accepted for recording in the office of the Clerk of the Superior Court of Quitman County except a final plat on which is inscribed the approval of the County Commission. Section 404. - Use of Plat. The transfer of, sale, agreement to sell, or negotiate to sell land by reference to or exhibition of, or other use of a subdivision that has not been given final approval by the County Commission and recorded in the office of the Clerk of Superior Court of Quitman County is prohibited, and the description by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document shall not exempt the transaction from the requirements of this section. Section 405. - Erection of Buildings. No building shall be erected on any lot unless the street giving access thereto has been accepted as a public street or approved by the Commission as a private street as having been constructed in conformity with the County standards in accordance with this ordinance, or unless such street has attained the legal status of a public street prior to May 9, 1995, or has been accepted as a public street by the County Commission. Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14. Section 406. - Acceptance of and Improvements in Unapproved Streets. The County Commission of Quitman County or other public authority shall not accept as a public street or shall not itself undertake or authorize the layout, opening, improving, grading, paving, lighting or the installation of water mains, sewers, connections or other facilities or utilities in any street unless such street is shown on a final plat approved by the County Commission or it has attained the legal status of a public street prior to May 9, 1995; provided, however, that the County Commission may locate, construct or accept any other street if the ordinance for such a street is first submitted to the County Commission for its review and approval. ARTICLE V. - PRE-APPLICATION PROCEDURES
Section 501. - Discussion. Before proceeding with a proposed land subdivision, developers are invited and encouraged to discuss their proposed development with the board of commissioners or its designee. A very preliminary sketch of the proposed subdivision together with a map of the area showing its principal features will be helpful in this discussion. ARTICLE VI. - PROCEDURE FOR APPROVAL OF PRELIMINARY PLAT
Section 601. - Application for Preliminary Plat Approval. The subdivider shall submit to the Office of the board of commissioners or its designee, at least twenty (20) days prior to the next regular meeting of the County Commission, the following: 1. A letter requesting review and approval of a preliminary plat, giving the name and the address of the person to whom the notice of the hearing by the County Commission on the preliminary plat shall be sent. 2. Five copies of the preliminary plat and other documents, as specified in Article VII. 3. A preliminary plat filing fee of $25.00, plus the current cost of publishing the public notice. Section 602. - Review of Preliminary Plat. The board of commissioners or its designee shall check the plat for conformance to the regulations of this ordinance and if the preliminary plat is found to be in compliance, the board of commissioners or its designee will schedule the consideration of the preliminary plat on the agenda at the next Commissioners' meeting. However, if the preliminary plat is found to be deficient, the consideration of the preliminary plat will not [be] placed on the agenda for the next Commissioner's meeting, and the board of commissioners or its designee will notify the developer in writing of the deficiencies. The developer will have an opportunity to correct the deficiencies and resubmit the plat to the board of commissioners or its designee. If the plat has been resubmitted to the board of commissioners or its designee at least five (5) days prior to the next meeting of the Commissioners, the consideration of the preliminary plat will be placed on the agenda for its consideration by the Commissioners. If the plat is resubmitted less then [than] five (5) days prior to the next meeting of the Commissioners, the consideration of the plat will be placed on the agenda at the next following meeting. The County Commission shall approve or disapprove the preliminary plat. A notation of the action shall be made on two copies of the preliminary plat, including a statement of the reasons for disapproval if the preliminary plat is disapproved. One copy shall be returned to the subdivider or his agent and one copy added to the records of the board of commissioners or its designee. Approval of a preliminary plat does not constitute approval of a final plat. It indicates only approval of the layout as a guide to preparation of the final plat. Preliminary plat approval shall expire and be null and void after a period of one year unless an extension of time is approved by the board of commissioners or its designee pursuant to uniform county standards. Section 603. - Public Notice. The board of commissioners or its designee shall cause the public notice defined in this paragraph to be published in the local paper. If the preliminary plat has not been waived, the public notice shall be run in the local paper at least once before the date set for the County Commissioners' consideration of the preliminary plat. If the approval of the preliminary plat has [been] waived, the board of commissioners or its designee shall publish a notice once in the paper before the next meeting of the County Commissioners after it has received the preliminary plat. The notice shall contain the name of the developer, the public road the subdivision is located on, or the public road access to the subdivision is obtained from, and the land lot number(s) and the district number(s) in which the subdivision is located. ARTICLE VII. - PRELIMINARY PLAT SPECIFICATIONS Preliminary plats for subdivisions shall be prepared as follows:
Section 701. - Scale. The preliminary plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn at a scale not smaller than 100 feet to one inch. Section 702. - Sheet Size. Original Sheet size shall be 24 × 36 inches. If the complete plat cannot be shown on one sheet of this size, it may be shown on more than one sheet with an index map on a separate sheet of the same size. Section 703. - Information to be Provided in Preliminary Plat. The preliminary plat shall contain the following information: 1. Name and address of owner(s) of record and of subdivider(s); 2. Proposed name of subdivision and its gross acreage; 3. North arrow, graphic scale and date; 4. Vicinity map showing location of the subdivision and developments in its vicinity; 5. Exact boundary lines of the tract by bearings and distances from a referenced point of beginning; 6. Names of owners of record of adjoining land; 7. Existing streets, utilities and easements on the land adjacent to the tract; 8. Contour lines at intervals of not more than 2 feet; 9. Proposed layout including streets, and alleys, if the subdivision contains alleys, with proposed street names, lot lines with approximate dimensions, easements, land to be reserved or dedicated for public uses, and any land to be used for purposes other than single-family dwellings; 10. Lots shall be consecutively numbered so that no two lots have the same lot number; 11. Provisions for water supply, sewerage and drainage; 12. Minimum building front-yard setback lines; 13. Such street cross-sections and center-line profiles as may be required by the Planning Department; 14. Present and proposed wells, watercourses, floodplains and wetland areas, water systems, sewage systems, structures and easements on the property and within 100 feet of the perimeter of the property; and 15. Present public water systems and public sewage systems, within 1,000 feet of the perimeter of the property. Section 704. - Certificate of Approval. A certificate of approval of the preliminary plat by the County Commission shall be inscribed on the plat as follows: "Pursuant to the Land Subdivision Regulations of Quitman County, Georgia, all the requirements of approval having been fulfilled, this preliminary plat was approved by the Quitman County Commission on ________, ___. This approval of the preliminary plat does not constitute approval of a final plat. This certificate of approval of the preliminary plat shall expire and be null and void until amended, modified or evoked by proper resolution."
Section 705. - Waiver of the Preliminary Plat Procedures. The approval of the preliminary plat can be waived if so recommended by the board of commissioners or its designee and approved by the County Commission. The preliminary plat procedure will be considered waived if the lots being subdivided are located on a paved county road and there are no new roads (public or private) to be constructed in the subdivision. Prior to such a recommendation, the board of commissioners or its designee is to determine if the subdivider has successfully, with good standing, completed a minimum of three subdivisions, of which at least two are in Quitman County. The final authority [for] the waiver of the approval of the preliminary plat rests on the County Commission. The remaining preliminary plat requirements still apply. Section 706. - Initiation of Improvements. After a preliminary plat has been approved, no improvements in the land subdivision shall be undertaken until final engineering plans and specifications have been approved by the County. ARTICLE VIII. - FINAL PLAT PROCEDURE
Section 801. - Application for Final Plat Approval. After the preliminary plat of a proposed land subdivision has been approved by the County Commission, the subdivider may, within one year from approval, submit to the board of commissioners or its designee: 1. A letter requesting review and approval of a final plat, giving the name and address of the person(s) to whom the notice of the hearing by the County Commission on the final plat shall be sent. 2. Five copies of the final plat and other documents, as specified in Article IX, the original of which shall be drawn in permanent ink on reproducible sepia paper or reproducible format, and in conformity with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 15-6-67. The copies submitted to the board of commissioners or its designee and for recording in the Clerk's Office can be a blue-lined copy. 3. The subdivider shall be responsible for paying the recording fees as specified by the Clerk of the Superior Court of Quitman County. Section 802. - Review of Final Plat. The board of commissioners or its designee shall check the final plat for the following requirements: 1. The board of commissioners or its designee shall check the plat for conformance to the regulations of this Ordinance, and if the final plat is found to be in compliance, the board of commissioners or its designee will schedule the consideration of the final plat on the agenda at the next County Commissioners' meeting. However, if the final plat is found to be deficient, the consideration of the final plat will not be placed on the agenda for the next Commissioners' meeting, and the board of commissioners or its designee will notify the developer in writing of the deficiencies and give the developer an opportunity to correct the deficiencies. The consideration of the final plat shall be placed on the Commissioners' agenda at the second meeting that occurs after the final plat has been submitted. 2. If the preliminary plat is waived by the County Commission according to the procedures and requirements outlined in Section 705, the County Commission shall examine and approve the final plat using the plat specifications outlined in Article VII. 3. The County Commission shall approve or disapprove the final plat. A notation of the action shall be made on the original tracing and two prints of the final plat, including a statement of the reasons therefor if the final plat is disapproved. Section 803. - Approval of Final Plat. 1. Upon approval of the final plat, the board of commissioners or its designee will notify the subdivider, and [the] subdivider may, within one (1) year, proceed to build the roads, lay the utility lines, stormwater and sanitary sewer lines. 2. The Building Inspector, after receipt of the funds from the developer to pay the Clerk's recording fee of the final plat, shall record the final plat in the Office of the Clerk of the Quitman Superior Court. Subsequent to the recording of the final plat, with all certificates endorsed thereon, a copy shall be filed with the records of the board of commissioners or its designee and the recording information of the plat shall be indicated on the copy. ARTICLE IX. - FINAL PLAT SPECIFICATIONS
Section 901. - Final Plat Requirements. The final plat shall conform to and meet the specifications of the preliminary plat and the following additional specifications: 1. The original final plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn in permanent ink on reproducible copy paper or other reproducible media at a scale not smaller than 100 feet to one inch. Blue-lined copies of the original plat will be accepted. Original sheet sizes shall be 24 × 36 inches, and where more than one sheet is required, an index map shall be provided on the same size sheet. The final plat shall show: a. Bearings and distances of the subdivision boundaries to the nearest existing street lines or other permanent monuments (not less than three) accurately described on the plat. b. Municipal, county and land-lot lines accurately tied to the boundary lines of the subdivision by distance and angles when such lines traverse or are reasonably close to the subdivision. c. Exact boundary lines of the tract, determined by a field survey, giving distances to the nearest one-tenth foot and angles to the nearest minute, which shall be balanced and closed with an error of closure not to exceed one to five thousand. d. Name of subdivision, exact location, widths, and names of all streets and alleys within and immediately adjoining the plat. e. Street center-lines showing angles of deflection, angles of intersection, radii and lengths of tangents. f. Lot lines with dimensions to the nearest one-tenth foot. g. Lots numbered in numerical order. h. Location, dimensions, and purposes of any easements and any areas to be reserved or dedicated for public use. i. Accurate location, material and description of monuments and markers. j. A statement, either directly on the plat or in an identified attached document, of any private covenants. k. The actual location of all utility lines. l. Profiles and invert elevations of all stormwater and sanitary sewer lines. m. The following certifications: (1) An Engineer's or Surveyor's Certification, directly on the final plat as follows: "It is hereby certified that this plat is true and correct and was prepared from an actual survey of the property by me or under my supervision; that all monuments shown thereon actually exist and their location, size, type and material are correctly shown; and that all engineering requirements of the Land Subdivision Regulations of Quitman County, Georgia, have been fully complied with.
(2) An Owner's Certification, directly on the final plat as follows: "Owner's Certificate State of Georgia, County of Quitman." "The owner(s) of the land shown on this plat and whose name(s) are subscribed hereto, in person or through a duly authorized agent, certifies that this plat was made from an actual survey, that all state and county taxes or other assessments now due on this land have been paid."
(3) Certificate of Dedication. A certificate by owner(s) setting forth the description of the areas and improvements dedicated to the public and the extent of the title of the dedication shall be attached to the final plat. Because of the legal consideration here, this certificate shall be approved as to the form by the County Attorney. (4) A Certificate of Approval of the Final Plat by the County Commission, directly on the plat, as follows: "Pursuant to the Land Subdivision Regulations of Quitman County, Georgia, all the requirements of approval having been fulfilled, this final plat was approved by the Quitman County Commission on ________, ___."
ARTICLE X. - AS-BUILT PLAT PROCEDURE
Section 1001. - As Built Plat Requirements. The as-built plat shall conform to and meet the specifications of the final plat specifications and the requirements of Section 804. Section 1002. - Filing and Recording of As Built Plat. 1. After the subdivision, or a phase of the subdivision, if the subdivision is developed in phases, has been developed, the subdivider shall present to the board of commissioners or its designee the as-built plat, which shall include the following: (a) Three copies, 18 × 24, of the subdivision plat, or that portion that has been completed. (b) The actual location of all utility lines. (c) Profiles and invert elevations of all stormwater and sanitary sewer lines, as built. (d) Centerline profiles of all streets, as-built. (e) One complete set of construction plans and drawings. 2. Upon receipt of the as-built plat as defined above, the Building Inspector shall inspect the plat for compliance with the above requirements. If the above requirements have been satisfied, the Building Inspector shall place the consideration of the as-built plat on the agenda at the next Board of Commissioners' meeting. If the as-built plat is deficient, the Building Inspector shall not place the consideration of the as-built plat on the next agenda, but shall notify the developer in writing of the deficiencies. The developer will have an opportunity to correct the as-built plat and re-submit the as-built plat to the board of commissioners or its designee. If the as-built plat has been re-submitted to the board of commissioners or its designee at least five (5) days prior to the next meeting of the Commissioners, the consideration of the as-built plat will be placed on the agenda for its consideration by the Commissioners. If the as-built plat is submitted less than five (5) days prior to the next meeting of the Commissioners, the consideration of the as-built plat will be placed on the agenda at the next following meeting. 3. The streets of the subdivision shall not be accepted by the Board of Commissioners until the as-built plat has been accepted and approved by the Commissioners. Upon acceptance and approval of the as-built plat, the following certification shall be affixed to the final as-built plat: "Pursuant to the Land Subdivision Regulations of Quitman County, Georgia, all requirements of the as-built plat having been fulfilled, this as-built plat was approved by the Quitman County Commissioners on the _____ day of ________, ___.
ARTICLE XI. - GENERAL DESIGN REQUIREMENTS
Section 1101. - Suitability of Land. Land subject to flooding, improper drainage or erosion or land that is for topographical or other reasons unsuitable for residential use shall not be platted for residential use nor for any other use that will continue or increase the danger to health, safety or property destruction, unless the hazards can be and are corrected. The Board of Commissioners shall seek advise from public works and the County Engineer and public health officials and others as deemed appropriate by the Board of Commissioners on the suitability of land for residential use. Section 1102. - Name of Subdivision. The name of the subdivision shall not duplicate nor closely approximate the name of any existing subdivision. The name of the subdivision shall be posted on a permanent, weather proof sign, minimum size 4 × 4 feet and maximum size 4 × 8 feet, located at the main entrance or entrances of the subdivision, and not obscured by any shrubs, trees, hedges or structures. Section 1103. - Access. Access to every subdivision shall be provided over a public street, however, the streets in the subdivision may be private streets. Section 1104. - Dams. The subdivisions will not be accepted or approved if the only entrance or access is over a dam. Primary access must be provided over a public street that does not traverse a dam. Section 1105. - Conformance to adopted Comprehensive Plan. (Reserved) Section 1106. - Features of other plans. When features of other plans adopted by the County Commission (such as schools or other public-building sites, parks, or other land for public uses) are located in whole or in part in a land subdivision, such features shall be either dedicated or reserved by the subdivider for acquisition within a reasonable time by the appropriate public agency. Section 1107. - Unsuitable land for public use. Whenever a plat proposes the dedication of land to public use that the County Commission finds not required or suitable for such public use, the County Commission shall refuse to approve the plat, and shall notify the land developer of the reasons for such action. Section 1108. - Large-Scale Developments. The requirements of this resolution may be modified in the case of a large-scale community, or planned-unit developments such as a housing project or shopping center which may or may not be subdivided into customary lots, blocks and streets, if the development meets the requirements of the ordinances of Quitman County, Georgia, is approved by the County Commission and if it is in conformity with the purpose and intent of this ordinance. Section 1109. - Lots on Existing Dirt Road. When a developer subdivides lots on an existing dirt road, and the existing right-of-way for the dirt road is less than the minimum right-of-way for county paved roads, the developer shall reserve sufficient right-of-way, as measured from the centerline of the future paved road, as set by the County Engineer, for the future widening and improvement of the road. The developer shall convey a vested future interest in the reserved right-of-way to the County and the title to the right-of-way shall vest in the County at such time as the County decides to pave the road. Written notice of such intention to the then land owner or land owners over whose land the reservation is situate, shall vest the title to the right-of-way in the County at no cost to the County. ARTICLE XII. - GENERAL REQUIREMENTS FOR STREETS AND OTHER RIGHTS-OF-WAY[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Roads and bridges, ch. 38.
Section 1201. - Continuation of Existing Streets. Existing streets shall be continued at the same or greater width, but in no case less than the required width. Section 1202. - Street Names. Streets that are obviously in alignment with streets existing and named shall be given the name of the existing street. Names of new streets shall not duplicate nor closely approximate those of existing streets. Section 1203. - Street Jogs. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall not be permitted. Section 1204. - Culs-de-Sac. Except where topographic or other conditions make a greater length unavoidable, culs-de-sac, or dead end streets, shall be not greater in length than 800 feet. They shall be provided at the closed end with a turn-around having a property line radius of at least 60 feet with an outside pavement radius of at least 50 feet. Section 1205. - Development Along Major Thoroughfare, Limited-Access Highway or Railroad Right-of-Way. Where a subdivision abuts or contains a major thoroughfare, a limited-access highway or a railroad right-of-way, the County Commission may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way either as [a] marginal access street or, at a distance suitable for an appropriate use of the intervening land, with a non-access reservation suitably planted; due regard shall be given requirements for approach grades and future grade separations in determining distances. Lots shall not have direct access to a major thoroughfare (or limited-access highway), but only to access streets. Section 1206. - Alleys. Alleys may be constructed at the rear of all lots, whether they are used for one family, multifamily, commercial or industrial purposes. If the subdivision contains alleys, such alleys [shall] provide access to the lot and a location for certain utilities, and facilitate garbage collection. Section 1207. - Easements. Easements having a minimum width of ten feet and located along the side or rear lot lines shall be provided, as required, for utilities. Section 1208. - Watercourse, Drain[age]way, Channel or Stream Traverse. Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater or drainage right-of-way of adequate width. Parallel streets may be required by the County Commission in connection therewith. ARTICLE XIII. - STREET DESIGN REQUIREMENTS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Cross reference— Roads and bridges, ch. 38.
Section 1301. - Street Specifications. All streets, public and private, shall be built, constructed, and paved in conformity with the County Standard Specifications for Roads and Streets. Section 1302. - Street Right-of-Way Widths. Street right-of-way widths shall be the distance across a street from property line to property line. Minimum street right-of-way widths shall be as follows: 1. Major thoroughfare widths shall be 80 to 100 feet, depending on the existence and size of a median strip, determination of which shall be made by the County Commission. 2. Collector streets, 80 feet. 3. Local streets, dead end streets, and culs-de-sac, 60 feet. 4. Interior streets, 60 feet. 5. Alleys, 20 feet. Section 1303. - Street Grades. (Reserved) Section 1304. - Street Intersections. Street intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as possible. No street intersections shall intersect at an angle of less than 60 degrees, unless required by unusual circumstances, and approved by the County. Section 1305. - Curbline Radius. The curbline radius at street intersections shall be at least 25 feet. Where the angle of [the] street intersection is less than 90 degrees, a longer radius may be required. Section 1306. - Street Paving Width. Street paving widths shall be no less than the following, measured from [the] edge of pavement: 1. Major thoroughfares with median (100-foot right-of-way), 2 at 28 feet each. 2. Major thoroughfares (80-foot right-of-way), 52 feet. 3. Local Streets (60-foot right-of-way) road bed, 34 feet, pavement 22 feet. 4. Interior Streets (60-foot right-of-way), 28 feet. Section 1307. - Street Improvement Specifications. All major thoroughfares, connector, interior and local streets within a subdivision shall be improved in accordance with County standards. ARTICLE XIV. - DESIGN STANDARDS FOR BLOCKS AND LOTS
Section 1401. - Block Lengths and Widths. Block lengths and widths shall be as follows: 1. Blocks shall be not greater than 1,800 feet nor less than 600 feet in length, except in unusual circumstances. 2. Blocks shall be wide enough to provide two tiers of lots of minimum depth, except where abutting upon major thoroughfares, limited-access highways, or railroads or where other situations make this requirement impracticable. Section 1402. - Lot Sizes. Residential lots shall conform to the minimum dimension and area requirements: 1. The minimum lot size shall be one (1) acre when the well and septic tank are located on the lot. 2. The minimum lot size shall be one-half (½) acre when the lot is served by the public water system, a private water system that has been approved by the state environmental protection division, or a public sewage system. 3. There shall be no more than four lots located on a cul-de-sac. Section 1403. - Minimum Building Lines. The minimum building set back line shall be as follows: 1. Front set back line, 40 feet. 2. Side set back line, 15 feet. 3. Rear set back line, 25 feet. Section 1404. - Double and Reverse Frontage Lots. Double frontage and reverse frontage lots shall be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. A planting screen easement of at least ten (10) feet, across which there shall be no right of access, shall be provided along the line of lots abutting such a traffic artery or other incompatible use. ARTICLE XV. - DAM SPECIFICATIONS
Section 1501. - Regulations. If the subdivision contains a pond or a lake, the following specifications and regulations shall apply: 1. All dams shall be built and constructed in conformity with the specifications of the state soil and water conservation commission and the state department of natural resources and shall be certified by a registered engineer. 2. All drawings of the dam specifications and construction shall be stamped and sealed by a certified registered engineer, and submitted to the board of commissioners or its designee before construction begins. 3. All subdivisions that have a pond or lake shall form a Homeowners Association prior to the selling of the first lot, and shall present to the Board of Commissioners at the time of approval of the final plat, a certificate of the Secretary of State certifying the existence of the Homeowners Association. 4. The articles of the Homeowners Association shall provide that the lot owners shall have a prorata ownership interest in the improvements of the subdivision owned by the Homeowner's Association, if any. It is recommended that upon eighty (80%) percent of the lots in the subdivision being sold, the developer convey title to the dam, lake and pond in the subdivision to the Homeowner's Association. 5. The County does not and will not accept title or responsibility for any dam or lake and will not accept title or responsibility for any street that traverses a dam, and the County does not and will not accept any responsibility for the maintenance of the dam or any street that traverses the dam. ARTICLE XVI. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS
Section 1601. - Street improvements and utilities. Prior to the approval of the final plat an agreement shall have been reached between the subdivider or his agent and the county government with regard to the installation of street improvements and utilities called for on the subdivision plat. The subdivider shall be required to have installed by the appropriate county agency at his expense or, with approval of the agency concerned, to himself install the following street improvements and utilities: 1. All street rights-of-way shall have ditches and tail ditches as required by the soil conservation requirements and by the County Standard Specifications for Roads and Streets. 2. When sanitary sewage facilities are available, sanitary sewer lines and manholes installed. 3. When public water supply is available, water mains within the subdivision with fire hydrants and with connections to each lot. Minimum diameter of water pipes shall normally be six inches. All required street improvements, utilities and monuments shall be built to standards specified by the agency responsible for each. All utilities to be installed in the streets shall be placed and the soil shall be compacted prior to paving. ARTICLE XVII. - GENERAL PROVISIONS
Section 1700. - Right-of-way easements for streets and roads. Right-of-way easements for streets and roads shall not be considered a part of a lot or open space, or front, rear, or side yard for the purpose of meeting yard requirements. Section 1701. - Lot Reduction Prohibited. No yard or lot existing on May 9, 1995, shall be reduced in dimension or area below the minimum requirements set forth herein. Yards or lots created after May 9, 1995, shall meet at least the minimum requirements established by this resolution. Section 1702. - Use of Substandard Lots of Record. Where the owner of a lot on May 9, 1995, does not own sufficient land to enable him to conform to the dimensional requirements of this resolution, such lot may nonetheless be used as a building site, provided that said lot requirements are not reduced below the minimum specified in this resolution by more than twenty (20) percent. If, however, the owner of two (2) or more adjoining lots with insufficient land dimensions decides to build on or sell off these lots, he must first combine said lots to comply with the dimensional requirements of the resolution. Any lot requiring dimensional waivers below the twenty (20) percent minimum set forth in this section may be approved by the County Commissioners, provided that further decreased dimensional requirements shall conform as closely as possible to the required dimensions. Section 1703. - Public Street Frontage. No building shall be erected on a lot which does not abut at least one hundred (100) feet on a public street, except when the public street is a cul-de-sac, and shall have a minimum frontage of fifty (50) feet on the cul-de-sac. Section 1704. - One Principal Building On a Lot. Only one principal building and its customary accessory buildings may be erected on any one lot after May 9, 1995. Section 1705. - Planted Buffer Strips. Where commercial or industrial districts abut residential or mobile home park development, a ten (10) foot-wide buffer strip shall be provided along the abutting property lines, and the ten (10) feet shall be added to the side or rear yard requirements as well as the lot width unless specified otherwise in this resolution. Such buffer strip shall be planted with evergreen trees or shrubs that grow at least eight (8) feet tall and provide an effective visual screen. Section 1706. - Vision Clearance. In all subdivisions no fence, wall, shrubbery, or other obstruction to vision between the heights of two-and-one-half (2½) feet and ten (10) feet above the finished grade of streets shall be erected, permitted, or maintained within twenty (20) feet of the intersection of the right-of-way lines of streets and railroads. Section 1707. - Access to Public Streets, or Private Streets. Access to public streets, or private streets, shall be maintained in accordance with the following requirements: 1. No building shall be erected on a lot which does not abut at least one hundred (100) feet on a public street, or private street, except when the public street, or private street is a cul-de-sac, and shall have a minimum frontage of twenty-five (25) feet on the cul-de-sac. 2. Any additional dwelling shall have access to a public street, or private street, by means of a passageway open to the sky at least fifteen (15) feet in width. 3. Local streets which will carry less than six hundred (600) vehicles per day may have access points as needed to fit the development. 4. For all developments fronting on a state highway, no final plat shall be approved until the approval of the Georgia Department of Transportation (DOT) has been obtained regarding access points, curb radii, drainage and related engineering design of concern to the DOT, and proof of their final approval has been submitted, all as required by O.C.G.A. § 32-6-150 et seq. Section 1708. - Corner Lots. On lots having frontage on more than one street at an intersection, the minimum front yard requirement may be reduced to one-half the regulated distance on the portion of the lot fronting on the street or streets of lesser importance. However, in no case shall the setback be reduced to less than fifteen (15) feet. The minimum front yard for the portion of the lot fronting on the street of greater importance shall be provided in accordance with the provisions established by this resolution for the district in which the lot is located. Section 1709. - Double-Frontage Lots. On lots having frontage on two streets, but not located on a corner, the minimum front yard shall be provided on each street in accordance with the provisions of this resolution. On lots having frontage on more than two streets, the minimum front yard shall be provided in accordance with the regulations set forth in this resolution on at least two (2) of the street frontages. The minimum front yard on the other frontage or frontages may be reduced along the other streets. Section 1710. - Front Yard Requirements. The setback requirements of this resolution shall not apply to any lot where the average setback on already built upon lots [is] located wholly or in part within one hundred (100) feet on each side of such lot and within the block and zoning district and required setbacks but not less than the average of the existing setbacks on the developed lots. However, in no case shall setbacks be less than fifteen (15) feet. Section 1711. - Code Requirements and State Regulations. All structures shall meet the requirements of The Georgia State Minimum Standard Codes, as adopted and amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, including, [but not limited to]: Georgia Department of Transportation Regulations Georgia State Fire Marshal Regulations Georgia State Department of Human Resources Regulations Georgia Erosion and Sedimentation [Act] of 1975 (O.C.G.A. § 12-7-1 et seq.), as amended ARTICLE XVIII. - LEGAL STATUS PROVISIONS[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2.
Section 1801. - Conflict with Other Laws. Whenever the regulations of this ordinance impose more restrictive standards than are required under any other ordinance or statute, the requirement of this ordinance shall govern. Whenever the provisions of any other ordinance or statute require more restrictive standards than are required by this ordinance, the provisions of such statute shall govern. Section 1802. - Separability. Should any section or provision of this ordinance be declared invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction such declaration shall not affect the validity of the ordinance as a whole or any part thereof which is not specifically declared to be invalid or unconstitutional. Section 1803. - Repeal of Conflicting Resolutions. All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. Section 1804. - Violation and Penalty. Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this ordinance shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand dollars for each offense. Each day such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. The county or any owner of real estate who would be damaged by such violation, in addition to other remedies, may institute injunction, mandamus or other appropriate action or proceeding to stop the violation. Section 1805. - Effective Date. This ordinance shall take effect and be in force from and after the date of its adoption, the public welfare demanding it. ARTICLE XIX. - AMENDMENTS This ordinance may be amended from time to time by the county commission but no amendment shall become effective unless it shall have been proposed by or shall first been submitted to the County Commission for review and recommendation. Before the County Commission enacts this ordinance or an amendment to it the Commission shall hold a public hearing thereon, at least fifteen days notice of the time and date of which shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. Unanimously adopted in regular session, this 9th day of May, 1995.
